question_text: A 65-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He takes no medications. Physical examination and laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Compared to a healthy adolescent, this patient is most likely to have which of the following changes in immune function?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He takes no medications. Physical examination and laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Compared to a healthy adolescent, this patient is most likely to have which of the following changes in immune function?
hint: Age is associated with physiologic changes in certain immune functions, including a decrease in CD4+ T-cell numbers.
learning_objective: Recall the effect of aging on immune response to vaccines.

answers.explanation_why: With increasing age, autoimmunity is increased rather than decreased because the synthesis of T_reg cells decreases and the synthesis of autoantibodies increases.
The phagocytic ability of neutrophils is decreased in older individuals, but the number of circulating neutrophils or neutrophil precursors are not affected by aging.

With advancing age, the ability of the body to mount antibody and cell-mediated immune responses to a new antigen decreases. This is caused by a decline in the counts of most subsets of B cells and T cells. The decreased immune response is also caused by impaired affinity maturation and V(D)J recombination, an increase in the proportion of monoclonal cell lines, and decreased affinity of antibodies for new antigens due to a decrease in the variety of B-cell receptors for antigens. These changes lead to an increased need for booster vaccinations in older adults.

answers.content: Increased number of circulating B cells
answers.explanation_why: The number of circulating B cells as well as the number of B-cell precursors decreases with advanced age because of senescence-related alterations in the microenvironment of the bone marrow and impaired responsiveness to growth-stimulating cytokines.

answers.content: Increased antibody affinity for foreign antigens
answers.explanation_why: The affinity of antibodies for antigens decreases rather than increases with age. This is primarily because of impaired affinity maturation, impaired V(D)J recombination, a decrease in the variety of B-cell receptors, and an increase in the proportion of monoclonal cell lines.
In older individuals, the amount of complement protein produced by the liver is less when compared to younger individuals.

question_text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, difficulty falling asleep, and night sweats for the past 6 months. Over the past year, her menstrual cycle has become irregular and her last menstrual period was 2 months ago. She quit smoking 2 years ago. Pelvic exam shows vulvovaginal atrophy. A pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following changes is most likely to occur in this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, difficulty falling asleep, and night sweats for the past 6 months. Over the past year, her menstrual cycle has become irregular and her last menstrual period was 2 months ago. She quit smoking 2 years ago. Pelvic exam shows vulvovaginal atrophy. A pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following changes is most likely to occur in this patient's condition?
hint: This 47-year-old patient presents with irregular menses, night sweats, insomnia, and vulvovaginal atrophy, which are all signs and symptoms of menopause. The median age at onset of menopause in the United States is 51, but smoking is associated with earlier onset of symptoms.
learning_objective: Recognize the signs and symptoms of menopause, and recall the hormonal changes associated with it.

answers.explanation_why: An increase in luteinizing hormone (LH) would be seen during menopause rather than a decrease. Ovarian failure leads to a decrease in the circulating levels of estrogen and progesterone, resulting in a decrease in negative feedback to the hypothalamus, and a subsequent increase in LH.

Estrogen levels often fluctuate during perimenopause but are more likely to be decreased, not increased, due to declining ovarian function. At menopause, ovarian production of estrogen ceases completely due to ovarian failure. After menopause, the majority of estrogen is derived from the peripheral conversion of testosterone via aromatase. Obese patients may have milder symptoms, as adipose tissue contains higher concentrations of aromatase.

Inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells. Levels of Inhibin B decrease during perimenopause, reflecting a decline in ovarian function, disappearing altogether shortly before menopause. Therefore, decreased, not increased, levels of inhibin B would be expected in this patient.

Testosterone levels during menopause are typically normal not increased. Increased testosterone can be a cause of anovulation and amenorrhea in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), but this patient has no signs of hirsutism or an adnexal mass on pelvic exam, making PCOS an unlikely diagnosis.

An increase rather than a decrease in gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) would be seen during menopause because menopause disrupts the pituitary-hypothalamic feedback mechanism. Low GnRH levels are seen, e.g., in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which may be congenital (Kallmann syndrome) or seen in secondary amenorrhea (excessive exercise, stress, reduced caloric intake etc.).

Increased levels of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) are most likely to be seen in this patient. Menopause is usually preceded by the climacteric period, in which the menstrual cycles become increasingly irregular before amenorrhea begins. Ovarian failure leads to a decrease in the circulating levels of estrogen and progesterone, resulting in a decrease in negative feedback to the hypothalamus. This results in an increase in GnRH levels and subsequent increase in FSH.

Due to the wide variability of FSH levels in women, it is no longer routinely tested to diagnose menopause, which is instead determined on a clinical basis.

question_text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of dull, persistent pain and swelling of her right leg. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Two years ago, she developed acute deep vein thrombosis in her right calf after a long flight, which was treated with anticoagulants for 6 months. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of her right leg. The skin around the right ankle shows a reddish-brown discoloration and multiple telangiectasias. She has dilated varicose veins in the right leg. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of dull, persistent pain and swelling of her right leg. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Two years ago, she developed acute deep vein thrombosis in her right calf after a long flight, which was treated with anticoagulants for 6 months. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of her right leg. The skin around the right ankle shows a reddish-brown discoloration and multiple telangiectasias. She has dilated varicose veins in the right leg. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?
hint: This patient's unilateral chronic dull pain, edema, dilated veins in the lower extremity, and history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) suggest chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).
learning_objective: Recognize chronic venous insufficiency, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Computed tomography scan with contrast of the lower extremities is used to evaluate patients for deep infections (e.g., abscesses), malignancy, or injury in the lower extremities. It is not used to evaluate for CVI.

Nerve conduction studies are used to evaluate the function of the peripheral nervous system. They are particularly critical for diagnosing polyneuropathies (e.g., due to chronic diabetes mellitus). Although polyneuropathy can manifest with asymmetric or unilateral pain, which is seen in this patient, the pain usually takes the form of a buzzing or tingling sensation, not a dull ache. Moreover, polyneuropathy would not cause the edema and telangiectasias seen in this patient.

The D-dimer assay is a nonspecific test that is indicated for patients with a low pretest probability of acute DVT to rule out an acute thrombotic event. The test has a high negative predictive value (> 95%); therefore, a negative test result effectively rules out the presence of a DVT or a pulmonary embolism.

The ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is used to screen for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in patients who present with lower limb pain that suggests claudication pain (i.e., pain on walking that is relieved with rest). This patient's pain improves with walking, making PAD an unlikely cause of her symptoms. Her symptoms are consistent with CVI, which cannot be evaluated with ABPI.

Duplex ultrasonography (compression ultrasonography) is the first-line investigation in patients with features suggestive of CVI, as seen here. Evidence of venous reflux on duplex ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis of CVI. Duplex ultrasonography can help determine the course of treatment by identifying which valves are incompetent and assessing the patency of the previously thrombosed deep veins.

question_text: A healthy 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for advice on UV protection. She works as an archaeologist and is required to work outside for extended periods of time. She is concerned about premature skin aging. The physician recommends sun-protective clothing and sunscreen. In order to protect effectively against photoaging, the sunscreen should contain which of the following active ingredients?
content_preview: A healthy 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for advice on UV protection. She works as an archaeologist and is required to work outside for extended periods of time. She is concerned about premature skin aging. The physician recommends sun-protective clothing and sunscreen. In order to protect effectively against photoaging, the sunscreen should contain which of the following active ingredients?
hint: Sunscreens that provide protection against both ultraviolet A (UVA) and ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation are recommended to prevent premature aging of the skin.
learning_objective: Recall the active ingredients in sunscreen that protect against photoaging.

answers.explanation_why: Trolamine salicylate absorbs UVB radiation but not UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

TMP/SMX is used to treat numerous infections (i.e., UTI, acne vulgaris, toxoplasmosis, impetigo, cellulitis). Although it is effective against skin infections, the sulfonamide component causes photosensitivity and increases the risk of skin damage from UVA and UVB radiation.

Topical vitamin E can reduce skin damage from UVB radiation. However, it does not provide protection from UVA radiation and therefore would still leave this patient at risk for premature aging of the skin.
Para-aminobenzoic acid is only able to filter out UVB radiation. This patient would not be protected from UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

Mineral-based sunscreens (e.g., with zinc oxide, titanium oxide) are broad-spectrum sunscreens and provide full protection from UVA and UVB radiation by absorbing light in those spectrums, which prevents penetration into the dermis and premature aging of the skin. Sunscreens that have salicylates (e.g., trolamine salicylate), para-aminobenzoic acid, cinnamates (e.g., cinoxate), or octocrylene as the active ingredient can absorb UVB radiation but not UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

question_text: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressive hair loss from his scalp. He first noticed receding of the hairline over the bitemporal regions of his scalp 5 years ago. Since then, his hair has gradually become thinner over the crown of his head. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Examination shows diffuse, nonscarring hair loss over the scalp with a bitemporal pattern of recession. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's hair loss?
content_preview: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressive hair loss from his scalp. He first noticed receding of the hairline over the bitemporal regions of his scalp 5 years ago. Since then, his hair has gradually become thinner over the crown of his head. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Examination shows diffuse, nonscarring hair loss over the scalp with a bitemporal pattern of recession. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's hair loss?
hint: This patient's history of gradual, nonscarring hair loss in a bitemporal pattern is consistent with androgenetic alopecia.
learning_objective: Recognize androgenetic alopecia, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Flutamide is a nonsteroidal competitive inhibitor of the androgen receptor that is sometimes used off-label for women with androgenetic alopecia. It is not used to treat male pattern baldness because of its adverse effects in men, including breast tenderness, feminization, hot flashes, and sexual dysfunction. Although flutamide is better tolerated among women, the evidence for efficacy is limited and there is a considerable risk of hepatotoxicity.

Habit reversal therapy is the treatment of choice for trichotillomania, a disorder characterized by the compulsion to pull out one's hair, which leads to nonscarring, patchy hair loss. However, the bald scalp areas are typically ill-defined and diffuse with hairs of varying length due to different points of breakage and/or pulling at different times, whereas this patient has gradual, nonscarring hair loss in a bitemporal pattern. Habit reversal therapy is not used to treat androgenetic alopecia.

images.title: Trichotillomania
images.description: There are patches of hair of varying length. The hair density is normal (including new hair growth).

answers.explanation_why: Griseofulvin is used to treat tinea infections such as tinea capitis, which typically causes round, pruritic, scaly plaques with broken hair shafts and irregular patches of hair loss, unlike this patient's manifestations. This condition is more common among young children but can develop in adults. Griseofulvin is not used to treat androgenetic alopecia.

images.title: Tinea capitis
images.description: Reddened, papular, and pustular round nodule can be seen on the scalp. Crusts, scaling, and alopecia are seen in the area of the lesion.The causative agent is the dermatophyte Microsporum gypseum. The white plaque is most likely topical antifungal cream.

answers.explanation_why: Intralesional triamcinolone is the first-line therapy for alopecia areata, which causes nonscarring hair loss similar to this patient's manifestations. However, alopecia areata typically causes acute-onset, well-demarcated patches of hair loss in contrast to this patient's chronic history of progressive and diffuse hair loss. Intralesional triamcinolone is not used to treat androgenetic alopecia.

images.title: Alopecia areata
images.description: There are well-demarcated, patchy areas of hair loss without scarring of the scalp.

answers.explanation_why: Levothyroxine is used to treat hypothyroidism, a trigger of telogen effluvium. Patients with telogen effluvium experience increased shedding of telogen hair; usually > 10% of hair can be removed if ∼ 50 hairs are grasped and gently tugged away from the scalp (positive hair pull test). Although the hair loss of telogen effluvium is diffuse and nonscarring, it is typically acute in onset. Additionally, this patient does not have signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, bradycardia, cold intolerance, constipation, weight gain). Levothyroxine is not used to treat androgenetic alopecia.

images.title: Telogen effluvium
images.description: Head of a patient 5 months after bariatric surgeryThe frontal (a) and the left side (b) of the scalp show a diffuse, nonscarring loss of hair. This appearance is caused by premature shedding of hair follicles in telogen phase (resting phase).Telogen effluvium can be caused, for example, by stress such as a surgery or severe febrile illness.

answers.explanation_why: Androgenetic alopecia follows an autosomal dominant or polygenic mode of inheritance with variable penetrance and is caused by increased androgen sensitivity of hair follicles. Dihydrotestosterone binds to androgen receptors on hair follicles and disrupts the anagen phase of hair growth. 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (e.g., finasteride) decrease the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone and are the first-line therapy for men with androgenetic alopecia. Adverse effects include gynecomastia and sexual dysfunction (e.g., decreased libido, erectile dysfunction). Topical minoxidil therapy is a first-line alternative.

images.title: Male pattern hair loss (androgenetic alopecia)
images.description: Non-scarring hair loss can be seen at the temporal scalp.This is the characteristic pattern of male pattern hair loss.

question_text: An 82-year-old man with Alzheimer disease is brought to the physician by his daughter because of extensive bruising on his arms. He lives in an assisted living facility. Physical examination shows large ecchymoses across both forearms and upper arms in varying stages of healing. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.7 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 78 μm^3, and platelet count is 180,000/mm^3. Coagulation studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's bruises?
content_preview: An 82-year-old man with Alzheimer disease is brought to the physician by his daughter because of extensive bruising on his arms. He lives in an assisted living facility. Physical examination shows large ecchymoses across both forearms and upper arms in varying stages of healing. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.7 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 78 μm3, and platelet count is 180,000/mm3. Coagulation studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's bruises?
hint: This patient's history of dementia and residing in an assisted living facility are risk factors for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize nonaccidental trauma as a cause of bruising in elderly patients.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's bruises on the upper extremity are most likely caused by nonaccidental trauma due to older adult abuse. Older adults, especially those with dementia, are at increased risk for abuse. Older adult abuse is most commonly perpetrated by caregivers (e.g., spouse, nursing home staff) and can be physical, psychological, or financial, or take the form of neglect. Physicians are legally and ethically obligated to report suspected abuse. When a physician suspects abuse, they should privately speak with the affected patient, ask for further information, and offer assistance.

Finally, this patient's decreased MCV and hemoglobin are consistent with microcytic anemia (e.g., due to insufficient iron intake) but do not indicate an increased bleeding risk.

Bruising due to platelet aggregation inhibition can be seen in patients on antiplatelet agents, and most commonly occurs in women > 60 years old who have recently started antiplatelet therapy (duration < 1 month). This patient with Alzheimer disease has a normal platelet count and coagulation studies, bruises in different stages of healing (localized to the upper extremity), and no history of antiplatelet use, all of which should raise concern for a different etiology.

Intravascular coagulation with fibrinolysis is consistent with a consumptive coagulopathy, such as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). This patient with bruises localized to the upper extremities, normal platelet count and coagulation studies, and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., due to sepsis or malignancy) is unlikely to have DIC.

Increased activity of epidermal melanocytes is seen in solar lentigo. Solar lentigines are commonly found on sun-exposed areas including the back of the hands, forehead, and scalp, but not the upper arms. The affected skin shows solitary or multiple dark, sharply demarcated, pigmented macules due to melanin, rather than purple/reddish poorly demarcated lesions due to hemoglobin breakdown.

Vitamin K deficiency causes large ecchymoses, which are seen here, and deep tissue bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis, hematomas). However, vitamin K deficiency is unlikely in this patient with normal coagulation studies.

question_text: One week after admission to the hospital for an extensive left middle cerebral artery stroke, a 91-year-old woman is unable to communicate, walk, or safely swallow food. She has been without nutrition for the duration of her hospitalization. She has advanced vascular dementia. The patient's sister requests placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube for nutrition. The patient's husband declines the intervention. There is no living will. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action by the physician?
content_preview: One week after admission to the hospital for an extensive left middle cerebral artery stroke, a 91-year-old woman is unable to communicate, walk, or safely swallow food. She has been without nutrition for the duration of her hospitalization. She has advanced vascular dementia. The patient's sister requests placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube for nutrition. The patient's husband declines the intervention. There is no living will. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action by the physician?
hint: If a patient lacks decision-making capacity, it is paramount that decisions be made based on what the patient would have wanted.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate action when addressing surrogate decision-making without a living will.

answers.explanation_why: Consulting the hospital ethics committee is appropriate if there is a complicated, unresolved ethical dilemma in which the stakeholders would benefit from the involvement of professionals (physicians, nurses, social workers, bioethicists) with advanced training in facilitating difficult decision-making. However, an ethics consult is more appropriate if there is a conflict between the four core bioethics principles of autonomy, beneficence, nonmaleficence, and justice. Disagreements between family members are routine in medical care, and the team should first attempt another course of action.
Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is not indicated in this patient because she can still receive enteral nutrition (e.g., PEG).

A family meeting with the patient's husband, sister, and members of the healthcare team could provide clarification as to what the patient would have desired had she been able to make the decision herself. Although the patient's sister and husband currently disagree, a discussion about the patient's own goals and values could encourage family agreement and facilitate better surrogate decision-making. If a resolution of the disagreement is not possible, the husband will most likely have the final say as his wife's next of kin.

The role of PEG placement in patients with dementia is controversial; studies have found no survival benefit or increase in quality of life in patients with advanced dementia who received PEG feeding compared with no tube feeding.

A request for a court-appointed guardian for a patient who lacks the capacity to make medical decisions is typically made when there is no medical power of attorney or next-of-kin available to serve as surrogate decision maker. In this scenario, the patient has multiple family members involved. Another approach would better facilitate reaching a decision in the best interests of the patient.

answers.content: Transfer to a physician specialized in hospice care
answers.explanation_why: Hospice care is not indicated here, as there is no suggestion that the patient is terminally ill and expected to live less than six months.

question_text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening lower back pain. The pain radiates down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot. She has had no trauma, urinary incontinence, or fever. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows disk degeneration and herniation compressing the S1 nerve root. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
content_preview: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening lower back pain. The pain radiates down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot. She has had no trauma, urinary incontinence, or fever. An MRI of the lumbar spine shows disk degeneration and herniation compressing the S1 nerve root. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
hint: S1 radiculopathy causes motor deficits in the gastrocnemius muscle.
learning_objective: Recognize S1 radiculopathy, and recall its effect on reflexes.

answers.explanation_why: Difficulty walking on heels (e.g., foot drop) is consistent with an injury to the L5 nerve roots (i.e., L5 radiculopathy). In addition, L5 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the dorsolateral thigh, the lateral side of the knee, lower leg, and dorsum of the foot and big toe.

An absent patellar reflex is consistent with an injury to the L3 and L4 nerve roots (i.e., L3 and L4 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause sensory deficits of the anterolateral area of the thigh. L4 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit extending along the anterolateral thigh, the area over the patella, the medial aspect of the leg, and the medial malleolus.

answers.content: Diminished sensation of the anus and genitalia
answers.explanation_why: Diminished sensation of the anus and the genitalia is seen in cauda equina syndrome. Although patients typically present with asymmetric, unilateral radicular pain in the lower limb dermatomes (due to a lesion below the level of L2), there are usually numerous spinal nerves (L3–S5) involved rather than an isolated nerve root (S1 dermatome) as seen in this patient. Furthermore, other expected findings (e.g., saddle block anesthesia, fecal incontinence, urinary incontinence or retention) are lacking in this patient.

S1 radiculopathy is caused by compression of the S1 spinal nerve root and can manifest with a weak Achilles tendon reflex. The S1 nerve root controls plantar flexion through the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, so weakness in these muscles can lead to a diminished Achilles tendon reflex and impaired toe walking. Additionally, the S1 nerve root controls sensation in the dorsolateral aspect of the thigh, the posterior calf, and the lateral side of the foot, which explains this patient's radiating pain in these regions.

answers.content: Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh
answers.explanation_why: Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh is consistent with an injury to the L3 nerve root (i.e., L3 radiculopathy). In addition, L3 radiculopathy would cause a sensory deficit of the anterolateral area of the thigh, as well as weakness of hip flexion, hip adduction, and knee extension.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe pain in her left hip after a fall this morning. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her only medication is a vitamin D supplement. Physical examination shows that her left leg is externally rotated and appears shorter than her right leg. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a fracture of the neck of the left femur. Which of the following changes in bone architecture is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe pain in her left hip after a fall this morning. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her only medication is a vitamin D supplement. Physical examination shows that her left leg is externally rotated and appears shorter than her right leg. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a fracture of the neck of the left femur. Which of the following changes in bone architecture is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The most likely cause of femoral neck fracture in a postmenopausal woman with a history of smoking is osteoporosis.
learning_objective: Recognize osteoporosis, and recall its effects on bone architecture.

answers.content: Overgrowth of cortical bone and reduced marrow space
answers.explanation_why: Overgrowth of cortical bone and reduced marrow space are found in osteopetrosis, which is caused by defective osteoclast activity. This results in thickened cortical bone that nevertheless breaks easily. Typical clinical manifestations are cranial nerve palsies, and pancytopenia, none of which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient's significant risk for osteoporosis indicates that she has a different change in bone architecture.

answers.content: Loss of cortical bone mass and thinning of trabeculae
answers.explanation_why:
Loss of cortical bone mass and thinning of trabecular bone are the microscopic hallmarks of osteoporosis. This patient has numerous risk factors for osteoporosis including female gender, advanced age, postmenopausal state, and tobacco use. In patients with osteoporosis, relatively minor trauma can cause fractures.

Postmenopausal women are especially prone to osteoporotic fractures due to increased bone resorption. This is caused by decreased estrogen levels, as estrogen stimulates osteoblasts and inhibits osteoclasts.

answers.content: Subperiosteal bone resorption and cystic degeneration
answers.explanation_why: Subperiosteal bone resorption and cystic degeneration are seen in hyperparathyroidism. Pathologically elevated parathyroid hormone levels inappropriately stimulate osteoclasts, causing bone catabolism, which can lead to fractures. However, hyperparathyroidism would be unlikely to present with an isolated fracture and no other manifestations such as nephrolithiasis, nausea, or constipation. Furthermore, this patient's significant risk for osteoporosis indicates that she has a different change in bone architecture.

Accumulation of inadequately mineralized osteoid is the pathophysiology of osteomalacia (in adults) and rickets (in children). In an adult patient, osteomalacia would most likely result from a vitamin D deficiency due to malnutrition, malabsorption, or chronic kidney disease. This patient, however, takes a vitamin D supplement, making a vitamin D deficiency unlikely.

answers.content: Formation of multiple sclerotic lesions in bony cortex
answers.explanation_why: Sclerotic bony lesions may occur due to bone metastases, vascular disease, or infection, and can predispose patients to femur fractures. However, this patient's significant risk for osteoporosis indicates that she has a different change in bone architecture.

answers.content: Deposition of lamellar bone interspersed with woven bone
answers.explanation_why: Deposition of lamellar bone interspersed with woven bone creates a 'mosaic' pattern that is classic for Paget disease of bone (PDB). PDB can present with pain and deformities in the affected bone but most commonly involves the skull (e.g., increased hat size, impaired hearing). Although Paget disease of bone can predispose patients to femur fractures, this patient's significant risk for osteoporosis indicates that she has a different change in bone architecture.

question_text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 2-week history of progressive disorientation and a 1-day history of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The wife reports that the patient had a minor fall 4 months ago, during which he may have hit his head. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He drinks 3–4 bottles of beer daily. He is only oriented to person. Neurological examination shows moderate spastic weakness, decreased sensation, and increased deep tendon reflexes in the left upper and lower extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 2-week history of progressive disorientation and a 1-day history of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The wife reports that the patient had a minor fall 4 months ago, during which he may have hit his head. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He drinks 3–4 bottles of beer daily. He is only oriented to person. Neurological examination shows moderate spastic weakness, decreased sensation, and increased deep tendon reflexes in the left upper and lower extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped, concave hemorrhage that crosses suture lines but not the midline. This finding is characteristic of a subdural hematoma (SDH).
learning_objective: Recognize chronic subdural hematoma due to tearing of bridging veins.

answers.explanation_why: Damage to the lenticulostriate arteries is most often a consequence of hypertension (Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm), cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or vasculitis. Patients typically present with severe headache, focal neurologic deficits, and loss of consciousness. The onset is acute and progresses rapidly. CT imaging would show a solitary hyperdense lesion, surrounded by hypodense edema within the cerebral parenchyma.

images.title: Basal ganglia hemorrhage
images.description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of chronic hypertensionHyperdense hemorrhage in the left basal ganglia is surrounded by hypodense perifocal edema (red overlay).The location is typical for hemorrhage from the lenticulostriate arteries as a result of long-standing hypertension.1: head of caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3 and green overlay: internal capsule; 4: thalamus
Arrowheads: calcified pineal gland; white circles: calcified choroid plexus

answers.explanation_why: Injury to the middle meningeal artery can lead to an epidural hemorrhage. The typical presentation of this injury is head trauma followed by normal sensorium (lucid interval) before onset of symptoms of increased intracranial pressure. CT scan would show a characteristic lentiform hemorrhagic collection (hemorrhage limited by suture lines).

images.title: Epidural and subdural hematomas
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (brain window: axial and coronal planes; bone window: axial plane)A biconvex epidural hematoma (green overlay) with mass effect is seen in the left frontal region, adjacent to which is a small frontotemporal subdural hematoma (red overlay). A calvarial fracture (arrowheads) involves the left temporal and parietal bones.

answers.explanation_why: Saccular aneurysm rupture leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage, which characteristically causes severe, abrupt-onset headaches (thunderclap headaches) that may be associated with vomiting, neck pain, and decreased levels of consciousness. While this patient has decreased levels of consciousness, he does not have any of the other characteristic symptoms, nor does his CT scan show blood in the subarachnoid space, as would be expected.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Regions of high attenuation (green overlay) in the interpeduncular cistern, Sylvian fissures, and left posterior fossa represent acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. The cerebellar tentorium (red overlay) should not be misinterpreted as blood.

answers.explanation_why: Embolus to the middle cerebral artery would cause an ischemic stroke. Most commonly, embolism results in acute-onset neurological defects as opposed to the subacute progression of this patient's symptoms. CT scans can present with a hyperdense MCA sign but are usually unremarkable for up to 24 hours after an ischemic stroke. MRI is the preferred modality for imaging acute ischemic stroke.

images.title: Acute ischemic stroke with hyperdense middle cerebral artery sign
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

answers.explanation_why:
SDH is caused by a rupture of the bridging veins, which cross the subdural space. This patient's history of minor head trauma followed by an insidious onset of disorientation is consistent with chronic SDH. The main risk factor for the development of this condition is diffuse cerebral atrophy associated with aging and/or chronic alcohol use. The new-onset unilateral neurological symptoms (spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, decreased sensation) are likely due to rebleeding.

See “Overview of intracranial hemorrhage” table.

images.title: Subdural hematoma: Etiology
images.description: Rupture of a bridging vein results in hemorrhage into the subdural space between the dura and arachnoid mater. Bleeding into the subdural space results in a crescent-shaped hematoma (right) that can cross suture lines but not the midline.

answers.explanation_why: Intraventricular vascular malformations are a common cause of intraventricular hemorrhage. Like other intracranial bleeding events, the characteristic presentation includes sudden onset of headache, vomiting, and altered level of consciousness. Seizures are common but focal neurological findings are not. CT imaging would show blood within the ventricular system.

images.title: Acute-on-chronic subdural hematoma
images.description: CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window)A crescent-shaped, heterogeneous lesion that crosses cranial sutures is visible on the anterolateral aspect of the right hemisphere. The anterior aspect of the lesion is hypodense (green overlay) indicating a chronic hematoma (serum extrusion and degradation of the clot decreases its radiodensity). The posterior aspect of the lesion is isodense to hyperdense (red overlay), indicating a recent hemorrhage into the existing hematoma (recent blood clots contain concentrated hemoglobin, which is hyperdense). Mass effect is visualized as a shift in the midline (white line) to the left (dashed white line), compression of the left lateral ventricle, and compression of the adjacent cerebral parenchyma, which appears edematous (hyperdense with loss of the sulci and gyri).These features are characteristic of an acute-on-chronic subdural hematoma.

question_text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual physical examination. He reports that his vision has progressively improved over the past 6 months and he no longer needs the glasses he used while driving. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Examination shows 20/20 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows a few microaneurysms of retinal vessels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's improved vision?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual physical examination. He reports that his vision has progressively improved over the past 6 months and he no longer needs the glasses he used while driving. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Examination shows 20/20 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows a few microaneurysms of retinal vessels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's improved vision?
hint: This patient's improvement in vision is likely due to presbyopia.
learning_objective: Recognize "second sight" in presbyopia, and recall its underlying cause.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased susceptibility to glare can be seen in darker colored eyes compared to lighter colored ones. However, it is an unlikely pathology. Increased susceptibility to glare is a finding of normal aging, most likely due to the effects of intraocular light scatter. It is increased in patients with cataract and would not present with an improvement in myopia in middle age.

Denaturation of lens proteins leads to the loss of lens elasticity seen in presbyopia, a classic condition associated with aging. This patient is experiencing the phenomenon of “second sight,” in which presbyopia corrects a long-standing case of myopia, resulting in improved visual acuity due to lens changes.

Liquefication of the vitreous humor is a physiological aging process that leads to condensing and shrinking of the gel-like substance. The vitreous membrane can eventually detach from the retina (posterior vitreous detachment). However, this would cause a worsening in the patient's vision (e.g., floaters, photopsia, scotoma), not an improvement.

Increased ciliary muscle tone is a mechanism that causes decreased diameter of the ciliary muscle, leading to constriction and accommodation of the pupil. It also induces opening of the trabecular meshwork and drainage of aqueous humor. It would be a mechanism for decreasing intraocular pressure in an ocular emergency like glaucoma, but it would not improve myopia during middle age. Furthermore, ciliary muscle tone tends to decrease with aging.

Macular degeneration is classified into two major forms: dry and wet macular degeneration. Dry macular degeneration is caused by the deposition of drusen under the retinal pigment epithelium, and wet macular degeneration is associated with neovascularization in the subretinal space. Both conditions cause decreased visual acuity, scotomas, and eventually blindness. However, since these conditions lead to progressively worsening central visual impairment in old age, they would not present with increasing visual acuity in middle age, as seen in this patient.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing wrinkles on her face and sagging skin. She says that her skin used to be smooth and firm. Examination shows diffuse xerosis and mild atrophy, laxity, and fine wrinkles on the periorbital skin. Which of the following processes is most likely involved in the development of this patient's skin findings?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing wrinkles on her face and sagging skin. She says that her skin used to be smooth and firm. Examination shows diffuse xerosis and mild atrophy, laxity, and fine wrinkles on the periorbital skin. Which of the following processes is most likely involved in the development of this patient's skin findings?
hint: This woman has normal, age-related changes of the skin.
learning_objective: Recall the effects of aging on skin, and recall the role of elastin fiber assembly.

answers.explanation_why: Lysyl oxidase activity does not change with aging. In fact, lysyl oxidase activity may even increase because cross-linked collagen is more stable in older skin than younger skin. This may be partly responsible for the toughness of older skin.

Collagen biosynthesis decreases rather than increases as skin ages. Simultaneously, collagen becomes disorganized. These changes are thought to be key factors in the overall decrease in skin strength and propensity to form wrinkles observed in aged skin.

Chronological aging of the skin, in particular of the dermis, is due in large part to the decreased assembly of elastin fibers. This accounts for increased skin laxity and rigidity. Atrophy of the dermis due to loss of collagen and volume deficit as a result of reduced glycosaminoglycan synthesis further contribute to the appearance of chronologically aged skin. Moreover, aging skin is prone to xerosis secondary to moisture loss resulting from diminished lipid and sebum production at the surface.

Age-related decrease of fibroblast activity contributes in large parts to the appearance of chronologically aged skin, as fibroblast synthesize collagens and components of the extracellular matrix, such as glycosaminoglycans (e.g., hyaluronic acid). Since GAGs maintain skin structure and moisture, decreased synthesis results in loss of volume and hydration, as well as the development of wrinkles and folds. Moreover, a decrease in fibroblast activity contributes to delayed wound healing.

Increased lipofuscin deposits in organs such as heart, colon, and eyes can be found in elderly persons as a sign of normal aging. Lipofuscin is also implicated in the pigmentation changes seen in aging skin. However, it is not known to contribute to structural changes in aging skin, such as sagging and wrinkles.

The crosslinking rate of collagen fibrils typically remains unchanged or increases slightly in older individuals. This is because the activity and abundance of the enzyme responsible for catalyzing collagen and elastin crosslinking remain relatively constant with time.

question_text: A 74-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for progressively worsening confusion and forgetfulness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a flat affect and impaired short-term memory. An MRI of the brain is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 74-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for progressively worsening confusion and forgetfulness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a flat affect and impaired short-term memory. An MRI of the brain is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: In conjunction with the MRI findings (marked dilatation of the lateral ventricles without proportional sulcal enlargement), this patient's progressively worsening confusion and memory suggest normal pressure hydrocephalus, a condition that is most commonly seen in adults over the age of 60.
learning_objective: Recognize normal pressure hydrocephalus, and recall its clinical triad.

answers.explanation_why: Startle myoclonus is seen in many neurological and psychiatric syndromes. When occurring in combination with signs of rapidly progressing dementia (rapidly worsening confusion and memory loss), Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease should be considered. However, MRI of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease would show T2 signal amplification in the caudate nucleus rather than the ventriculomegaly seen here.

images.title: MRI in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
images.description: MRI head (left: T2-weighted image, axial plane; right: diffusion-weighted image (DWI), axial plane) of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)The DWI shows hyperintensities (examples indicated by arrows) in the putamen (red overlay), thalamus (yellow overlay), and caudate nucleus (green overlay), common locations for deep gray matter involvement with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Sporadic CJD may also demonstrate ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri (cortical ribboning; not shown). A probable diagnosis of CJD can be made when expected MR imaging patterns are seen and CJD-mimicking disorders are confidently ruled out clinically.

answers.explanation_why: Papilledema can be due to either communicating hydrocephalus or noncommunicating hydrocephalus. While this patient does show signs of impaired consciousness (increasing confusion and forgetfulness), he lacks characteristic signs of elevated ICP (e.g., nausea, vomiting, headaches, Cushing triad), making papilledema unlikely. NPH, which this patient most likely has, is only characterized by a mild and intermittent elevation in ICP, and papilledema would not be expected.

A broad-based gait is a clumsy, irregular pattern of walk in which small steps are taken and the legs are spread wide. Gait dysfunction, dementia, and urinary incontinence make up the pathognomonic triad (“wet”, “wacky”, “wobbly”) of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Postural instability is one of the cardinal signs of Parkinson disease. Patients with the disease can present with cognitive dysfunctions and dementia, similar to what is seen in this patient, but only later in the course of the disease. Parkinson disease is not associated with ventriculomegaly, which is seen here.

Pill-rolling tremors are characteristic of Parkinson disease. Patients with the disease can manifest with cognitive dysfunctions and dementia, similar to what is seen in this patient, but only later in the course of the disease. Parkinson disease is not associated with the ventriculomegaly seen here.
answers.explanation_but: Imaging is not routinely required for the diagnosis of Parkinson disease. It is reserved for atypical presentations to rule out other underlying disorders.

answers.explanation_why: Choreiform movements are typically seen in Huntington disease. Huntington disease is associated with progressive cognitive deficits in advanced stages of the disease. MRI would show brain atrophy, particularly of the caudate nucleus, rather than the ventriculomegaly seen here.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial plane)There is marked dilatation of the lateral ventricles (green overlay) with mild sulcal enlargement (red overlay). The findings are suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus as opposed to age-related or neurodegenerative cerebral atrophy.Periventricular hypointensities (examples indicated by white arrowheads) are also seen and may reflect transependymal edema due to elevated cerebrospinal fluid pressure.

question_text: An otherwise healthy 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter because of a 1-day history of a diffuse headache and an inability to understand speech. There is no history of head trauma. He drinks 1–2 beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. His vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows fluent but meaningless speech and an inability to repeat sentences. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows an acute hemorrhage in the left temporal lobe and several small old hemorrhages in bilateral occipital lobes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's neurological symptoms?
content_preview: An otherwise healthy 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter because of a 1-day history of a diffuse headache and an inability to understand speech. There is no history of head trauma. He drinks 1–2 beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. His vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows fluent but meaningless speech and an inability to repeat sentences. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows an acute hemorrhage in the left temporal lobe and several small old hemorrhages in bilateral occipital lobes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's neurological symptoms?
hint: This elderly man presents with a spontaneous superficial intracerebral hemorrhage (i.e., a cortical lobar hemorrhage affecting the temporal lobe), which is most commonly caused by the deposition of a congophilic substance in the cortical blood vessels.
learning_objective: Recognize cerebral amyloid angiopathy as a cause of spontaneous lobar intracerebral hemorrhage in the elderly.

answers.explanation_why: Vascular lipohyalinosis of the cerebral vessel walls is the most common cause of spontaneous nontraumatic intracerebral hemorrhage, mostly presenting as a subcortical cerebral hemorrhage (lacunar strokes) within the basal ganglia. However, the most important predisposing factor for lipohyalinosis is chronic hypertension, which is absent in this patient's medical history.

images.title: Chronic lacunar infarcts
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Multiple, very small, sharply-demarcated hypodense lesions are present in the basal ganglia (green overlay), left internal capsule (blue overlay), and right thalamus (red overlay). Additionally, there is diffuse cerebral atrophy with prominence of the sulci and ventricles.

answers.explanation_why: A ruptured vascular malformation (e.g., saccular aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations) is a common cause of hemorrhage, which typically manifests with acute neurologic symptoms such as headache and aphasia. However, it is more common in younger patients, and radiological findings would show an acute intraparenchymal hemorrhage or subarachnoidal hemorrhage, not the acute and old cortical hemorrhages seen in this case.

Hypertensive encephalopathy is caused by a sudden sustained rise in blood pressure, which manifests with diffuse headache. However, affected individuals typically also present with vomiting, confusion, blurry vision, and papilledema, and their radiological findings show cerebral edema. Aphasia is not associated with this condition. Moreover, this patient has no history of hypertension.

Cardiac embolism is a cause of ischemic strokes, and its symptoms usually vary depending on the occluded cerebral vessel but may include headache and aphasia. However, they are typically seen in patients with cardiac wall and chamber abnormalities (e.g., patent foramen ovale) as well as valve disorders (e.g., prosthetic valves) and arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation), none of which this patient has.

images.title: Bilateral ischemic stroke in the calcarine sulcus
images.description: Coronal brain sectionThere is bilateral brown discoloration of the tissue below the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle and blurring of the cortex-medulla margin in the calcarine sulcus (red lines).These findings are the result of thromboembolic infarcts of the posterior cerebral arteries (outlined in green).A1: vascular territory of the anterior cerebral artery (green overlay); A2: middle cerebral artery (yellow overlay); A3: posterior cerebral artery (red overlay); 1: hippocampus; 3: corpus callosum; 4: lateral ventricle; 5: cingulate sulcus

answers.explanation_why:
Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is a common cause of spontaneous cortical intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) in elderly patients. CAA narrows the lumen of blood vessels and causes microaneurysms that may rupture spontaneously, which leads to recurrent lobar ICH. In this case, the patient's age (> 60 years of age), complete medical history (no history of trauma), focal neurological symptoms (aphasia), and radiological findings (both acute and subacute cortical hemorrhages) make CAA the most likely underlying cause of the hemorrhage.

Individuals with Alzheimer disease are at an increased risk of developing CAA.

question_text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because of a 1-month history of fatigue and a 3.5-kg (7-lb) weight loss. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and Alzheimer's dementia. She lives with her daughter and requires assistance with all of her banking and meal preparation. Her daughter has hypothyroidism, but there is no other history of serious illness in the family. The patient does not remember the names of her medications but says she takes them every day. Her pulse is 114/min and blood pressure is 148/101 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm skin and a tremor. The thyroid gland is not palpable. The serum thyroid stimulating hormone level is undetectable. Histological examination of a thyroid biopsy shows follicular atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because of a 1-month history of fatigue and a 3.5-kg (7-lb) weight loss. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and Alzheimer's dementia. She lives with her daughter and requires assistance with all of her banking and meal preparation. Her daughter has hypothyroidism, but there is no other history of serious illness in the family. The patient does not remember the names of her medications but says she takes them every day. Her pulse is 114/min and blood pressure is 148/101 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm skin and a tremor. The thyroid gland is not palpable. The serum thyroid stimulating hormone level is undetectable. Histological examination of a thyroid biopsy shows follicular atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient with mild cognitive impairment presents with unintentional weight loss, warm and moist skin, tachycardia, hypertension, and tremor, which are clinical symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
learning_objective: Recognize exogenous levothyroxine use as a cause of hyperthyroidism.

answers.explanation_why: Graves disease is an autoimmune condition in which TSH-receptor autoantibodies lead to overstimulation of the thyroid gland, causing hyperthyroidism and low TSH levels. This patient, however, does not have classic Graves disease features such as exophthalmos, goiter, and/or pretibial myxedema. Furthermore, a thyroid biopsy would show diffuse hyperplasia, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.

The combination of hyperthyroidism, an undetectable TSH level, and a thyroid biopsy showing follicular atrophy is most likely secondary to an unintentional exogenous intake of thyroid hormones. This patient's daughter has a history of hypothyroidism, for which she likely is taking levothyroxine. The patient's cognitive impairment has most likely led her to mistakenly take her daughter's medication, which has caused her to develop hyperthyroidism.

Granulomatous thyroiditis is a transient inflammatory condition associated with granuloma formation that can initially cause hyperthyroidism. However, it classically manifests with tender goiter, elevated ESR, and jaw pain. Furthermore, a biopsy would show diffuse granulomatous inflammation, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.

Increased iodine exposure can cause hyperthyroidism and occasionally occurs following treatment with high-dose iodine for autonomous thyroid nodules. However, this is a very rare cause of hyperthyroidism and would normally coincide with the presence of nodules or a goiter. Furthermore, a biopsy would demonstrate tissue hyperplasia, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.

Medullary thyroid cancer is a malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular C cells that can cause hyperthyroidism. However, it is an extremely rare cause of hyperthyroidism and would manifest with thyroid nodules or a neck mass. Furthermore, a biopsy would demonstrate parafollicular cell hyperplasia, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.

question_text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening coordination and involuntary movements in her left hand for the past 6 months. Her husband also reports that she has been withdrawn and apathetic during this period. She is oriented to time, place, and person. Examination shows a bimanual, rhythmic, low-frequency tremor that is more prominent in the left hand. There is normal range of motion in the arms and legs; active movements are very slow. Muscle strength is normal, and there is increased resistance to passive flexion and extension in the limbs. She walks with a shuffling gait and takes small steps. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening coordination and involuntary movements in her left hand for the past 6 months. Her husband also reports that she has been withdrawn and apathetic during this period. She is oriented to time, place, and person. Examination shows a bimanual, rhythmic, low-frequency tremor that is more prominent in the left hand. There is normal range of motion in the arms and legs; active movements are very slow. Muscle strength is normal, and there is increased resistance to passive flexion and extension in the limbs. She walks with a shuffling gait and takes small steps. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's muscle rigidity, low-frequency resting tremor, shuffling gait, bradykinesia, and a change in affect are consistent with parkinsonism. Given the unilateral onset of the tremor and the patient's age, the most likely diagnosis is Parkinson disease.
learning_objective: Recognize parkinsonism, and recall the pathophysiology of Parkinson disease.

answers.content: Accumulation of neurotoxic metabolites secondary to hepatocyte damage
answers.explanation_why: Accumulation of neurotoxic metabolites secondary to hepatocyte damage is characteristic of hepatic encephalopathy and must be ruled out in all patients with parkinsonian features, such as the low-frequency hand tremors and mood changes seen in this patient. It is important to note that asterixis is not a true tremor, but rather, myoclonic jerks that typically occur bilaterally in a nonrhythmic manner when the arms and hands are extended. Absence of decompensated liver failure features (e.g., jaundice, ascites) in this patient suggests that her parkinsonian features have a different pathogenesis.

answers.content: Copper accumulation due to mutations in hepatocyte copper-transporting ATPase
answers.explanation_why: A mutation to the copper-transporting ATPases primarily found in the liver (also sparingly seen in the kidneys and brain) is the underlying cause of Wilson disease. This condition is characterized by copper accumulation in the basal ganglia, which can cause parkinsonian features (e.g., resting tremors, bradykinesia, and rigidity). Although this patient has parkinsonian symptoms, she does not have the other characteristic findings seen in Wilson disease such as signs of liver disease, Kayser-Fleischer rings, and dysarthria.

answers.content: Neuronal degeneration due to α-synuclein protein misfolding
answers.explanation_why: Neuronal degeneration due to α-synuclein protein misfolding is the hallmark of Parkinson disease (PD), a disease characterized by the presence of eosinophilic inclusions known as Lewy bodies in the soma of neurons. Lewy bodies are aggregates of misfolded α-synuclein and other proteins and are also seen in patients with Lewy body dementia and multiple system atrophy (MSA). Although α-synuclein dysfunction is a key process in PD pathogenesis, the factors instigating neurodegeneration and the selective loss of dopaminergic neurons are multifaceted and still under investigation.

answers.content: Cerebellar ischemia due to chronic hypertension
answers.explanation_why: Cerebellar ischemia due to chronic hypertension is a major risk factor for cerebellar infarction, which may result in a tremor, as seen in this patient. Affected patients usually present with an acute intention tremor, i.e., it worsens with goal-directed movements, which causes dysmetria while performing the finger-nose test. Other signs of cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., nystagmus, abnormal gait, dysdiadochokinesia) would also be present. This patient has none of these features and her insidious onset of symptoms suggests that her current condition is of a different pathogenesis.
answers.explanation_but: The blood supply of the cerebellum consists of the posterior inferior cerebellar arteries (PICAs), branches of the vertebral artery, and the anterior inferior cerebellar arteries (AICAs) and the superior cerebellar arteries (SCAs), which arise from the basilar artery. Cerebellar infarcts require special attention because of the danger of cerebral edema within the posterior fossa, which can compress the brain stem causing potentially fatal transtentorial herniation (of the superior vermis through the tentorial notch) or downward herniation of the cerebellar tonsils (through the foramen magnum).

answers.content: Proliferation of beta-adrenergic receptors from excessive circulating T4
answers.explanation_why: Proliferation of β-adrenergic receptors from excessive circulating T4 in patients with hyperthyroidism may result in poorly controlled hypertension, anxiousness, and tremor. However, the tremor seen in hyperthyroidism would be bilateral, of high frequency (10–12 Hz), and not improve with movement.

question_text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician because of poor sleep for the past several months. Every night, he has difficulty falling asleep and does not get adequate rest. During the day, he has low energy and difficulty concentrating. Sleep hygiene and relaxation techniques have failed to improve his sleep. He denies snoring and headaches upon awakening. He has osteoarthritis of both knees and type 2 diabetes mellitus but is otherwise healthy. His medications include metformin and naproxen as needed. He would like to start a short-term trial of a medication for his sleeping problems but does not want to take any drugs with a high risk of side effects. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
content_preview: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician because of poor sleep for the past several months. Every night, he has difficulty falling asleep and does not get adequate rest. During the day, he has low energy and difficulty concentrating. Sleep hygiene and relaxation techniques have failed to improve his sleep. He denies snoring and headaches upon awakening. He has osteoarthritis of both knees and type 2 diabetes mellitus but is otherwise healthy. His medications include metformin and naproxen as needed. He would like to start a short-term trial of a medication for his sleeping problems but does not want to take any drugs with a high risk of side effects. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
hint: This 76-year-old patient presents with sleep-onset insomnia that is resistant to nonpharmacological interventions. Pharmacotherapy should generally be limited to several weeks and must be used cautiously, especially in older adults (> 65 years) because of the high risk of adverse effects. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient acts on the suprachiasmatic nucleus.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for sleep-onset insomnia in older adults.

answers.explanation_why: Intermediate-acting benzodiazepines, such as temazepam, should be avoided in older adults, as there is an increased risk of significant adverse effects such as cognitive impairment and falls with severe consequences (e.g., hip fracture). Moreover, this patient presents with sleep onset insomnia, so that a short-acting agent would be more appropriate. Although intermediate-acting benzodiazepines have a lower risk of the “hangover” effect compared to long-acting benzodiazepines, they have a higher risk for benzodiazepine dependence.

Barbiturates, such as phenobarbital, can be used in the treatment of insomnia. However, due to their significant adverse effects (e.g., tolerance, cardiorespiratory depression) and high risk of dependence, other classes of drugs are preferred.

Diphenhydramine is a strong sedative that belongs to the first-generation H1 receptor antagonists. However, antihistamines are not recommended for use in older adults due to their significant side effects (e.g., drowsiness, confusion, anticholinergic side effects).

Nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics, such as zolpidem, stimulate a specific type of GABA_A receptor. They have similar adverse effects as benzodiazepines (including impaired cognitive function, confusion, and psychomotor impairment), and should therefore only be considered for short-term use at the lowest possible dosage. Nonbenzodiazepines are effective for treating sleep onset insomnia and/or sleep maintenance insomnia, depending on their half-life. Zolpidem has a half-life of up to 4.5 hours and is associated with an increased risk of falls in older individuals, making it inappropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient.

Ramelteon is a melatonin receptor agonist that can be used to decrease sleep latency and increase total sleep time. Ramelteon has a benign side effect profile and is a preferred option in older patients because they are particularly sensitive to the adverse effects of sedative pharmacotherapy (e.g., cognitive dysfunction, psychomotor impairment, dependence, anticholinergic effects). Drugs that should be avoided in the management of insomnia disorder in older patients include benzodiazepines, nonbenzodiazepines, and antihistamines. Alternative agents in older patients include controlled-release melatonin and doxepin.

Long-acting benzodiazepines, such as flurazepam, should be avoided in older adults, as there is an increased risk of significant adverse effects such as cognitive impairment and falls with severe consequences (e.g., hip fracture). Moreover, this patient presents with sleep onset insomnia, so that a short-acting agent would be more appropriate. Although long-acting benzodiazepines have a lower risk of addiction compared to short-acting benzodiazepines, they have a higher risk of the “hangover” effect the day after they are used.

question_text: An otherwise healthy 65-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up visit for elevated blood pressure. Three weeks ago, his blood pressure was 160/80 mm Hg. Subsequent home blood pressure measurements at days 5, 10, and 15 found: 165/75 mm Hg, 162/82 mm Hg, and 170/80 mm Hg, respectively. He had a cold that was treated with over-the-counter medication 4 weeks ago. Pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 165/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including thyroid function studies, serum electrolytes, and serum creatinine, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's elevated blood pressure?
content_preview: An otherwise healthy 65-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up visit for elevated blood pressure. Three weeks ago, his blood pressure was 160/80 mm Hg. Subsequent home blood pressure measurements at days 5, 10, and 15 found: 165/75 mm Hg, 162/82 mm Hg, and 170/80 mm Hg, respectively. He had a cold that was treated with over-the-counter medication 4 weeks ago. Pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 165/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including thyroid function studies, serum electrolytes, and serum creatinine, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's elevated blood pressure?
hint: This elderly patient has a wide pulse pressure with elevated systolic blood pressure readings and normal diastolic pressures.
learning_objective: Recall the causes of isolated systolic hypertension in the elderly.

answers.explanation_why: A decrease in renal artery blood flow would activate the renin-angiotensin system and result in renovascular hypertension. Important causes of reduced renal artery blood flow include renal artery stenosis, external compression of the renal arteries (e.g., by a tumor or cyst), atherosclerosis of the renal arteries, and fibromuscular dysplasia. While atherosclerosis of the renal arteries should be considered given the patient's age, his normal diastolic pressures make another underlying cause more likely. Furthermore, only bilateral renal artery disease resulting in a significant decrease in GFR would manifest with hypertension; this patient's normal creatinine makes such a decrease unlikely.

A decrease in arterial compliance secondary to age-related reduction in arterial elasticity and increased stiffness is common in individuals > 60 years old. This decrease results in isolated systolic hypertension, which is characterized by a wide pulse pressure, as seen in this patient. Treatment with an antihypertensive agent, such as a thiazide diuretic or calcium channel blocker, should be initiated to decrease the risk of a cardiovascular event (e.g., myocardial infarction, stroke, or renal dysfunction).

Primary hyperaldosteronism is the most common cause of secondary hypertension and classically manifests with resistant hypertension and hypokalemia. The blood pressure seen in primary hyperaldosteronism is often markedly elevated and causes increases in both systolic and diastolic pressures. This patient's isolated systolic hypertension and normal lab values make this diagnosis unlikely.

answers.content: Increase in left ventricular end-diastolic volume
answers.explanation_why: Elevated LV end-diastolic volume, as seen in aortic regurgitation (AR), increases stroke volume and can also widen pulse pressure. However, AR alone would not cause this patient's hypertension, and a high-pitched, early diastolic murmur would be expected.

A decrease in baroreceptor sensitivity is the underlying mechanism of orthostatic hypotension. Unlike this patient's asymptomatic hypertension, it is characterized by autonomic dysfunction and insufficient counter-regulation after postural changes that leads to dizziness and syncope after standing up.

Most over-the-counter nasal decongestants contain sympathomimetics (e.g., phenylephrine, pseudoephedrine), which induce both local and systemic vasoconstriction. While these medications can cause hypertension, the time course of this patient's presentation and his isolated systolic pressures make a medication-induced etiology unlikely.

question_text: A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She has a history of hypertension well-controlled with diet and exercise. She has no history of smoking or illicit drug use. She walks 1 mile daily. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following age-related changes in respiratory function is most likely present in this patient?
content_preview: A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She has a history of hypertension well-controlled with diet and exercise. She has no history of smoking or illicit drug use. She walks 1 mile daily. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following age-related changes in respiratory function is most likely present in this patient?
hint: The patient lacks any history of respiratory disease and has a normal physical examination. Therefore, her change in respiratory function is likely a consequence of normal aging.
learning_objective: Recall age-related changes in respiratory function.

answers.explanation_why:
Increased lung compliance is commonly found in individuals of advanced age due to loss of elastic fibers. Chest wall compliance typically decreases because of increased chest wall stiffness. Stiffening of the chest wall and loss of elastic recoil impair lung emptying during expiration, which results in increased residual volume. When compared to a healthy young adult, individuals of advanced age have increased alveolar dead space and V/Q mismatch due to age-related loss of lung surface area. Moreover, while aging classically leads to a decrease in FEV_1  and vital capacity, total lung capacity usually remains unchanged.

Other age-related changes include decreased respiratory muscle strength (which can hinder effective coughing and increase the risk of aspiration and infection) and impaired ventilatory response to hypercapnia and hypoxia.
Vital capacity (VC = tidal volume + IRV + ERV) commonly decreases (not increases) with advanced age. This is primarily due to loss of elastic recoil and stiffening of the chest wall.

Residual volume can be decreased in restrictive lung disease. With advanced age, residual volume classically increases (not decreases) due to loss of elastic recoil and increased chest wall stiffening.

Decreased total lung capacity (TLC = vital capacity + residual volume) is classically seen in patients with restrictive lung disease. While normal aging is associated with an overall decrease in lung function, TLC will remain constant in the absence of respiratory disease.

In advanced age, age-related calcification of the chest wall and osteoporosis-mediated kyphosis lead to increased chest wall stiffness and decreased expansion of the thoracic cage during inspiration. Therefore, chest wall compliance classically decreases (not increases) with age.

The alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) compares the oxygenation status of alveoli and arterial blood. In advanced age, age-related loss of lung surface area increases alveolar dead space and V/Q mismatch. Increased V/Q mismatch results in hypoxia (↓ PaO_2), causing an increase (not decrease) in the A-a gradient.
