question_text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for forgetfulness, confusion, and mood changes for the past 4 months. His symptoms started with misplacing items such as his wallet and keys around the house. Two months ago, he became unable to manage their finances as it became too difficult for him. Last week, he became lost while returning home from the grocery store. His wife reports that he shows “no emotion” and that he is seemingly not concerned by his recent symptoms. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, metformin, and rosuvastatin. His pulse is 56/min and blood pressure is 158/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows loss of sensation on his right leg and an unsteady gait. When asked to stand with his eyes closed and palms facing upward, his right arm rotates inward. An MRI of the brain shows multiple deep white matter lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for forgetfulness, confusion, and mood changes for the past 4 months. His symptoms started with misplacing items such as his wallet and keys around the house. Two months ago, he became unable to manage their finances as it became too difficult for him. Last week, he became lost while returning home from the grocery store. His wife reports that he shows “no emotion” and that he is seemingly not concerned by his recent symptoms. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, metformin, and rosuvastatin. His pulse is 56/min and blood pressure is 158/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows loss of sensation on his right leg and an unsteady gait. When asked to stand with his eyes closed and palms facing upward, his right arm rotates inward. An MRI of the brain shows multiple deep white matter lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's clinical history (stepwise decline in executive function), physical examination (presence of focal neurologic deficits), and MRI findings (multiple deep white matter lesions) are suggestive of the second most common type of dementia in older individuals.
learning_objective: Recognize vascular dementia.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's presentation with a relatively abrupt cognitive decline and a stepwise deterioration in function (from misplacing items to being unable to manage finances to becoming lost in a familiar place) is suggestive of vascular dementia (i.e., multi-infarct dementia). The primary pathogenesis of this disease is atherosclerosis, for which diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and uncontrolled hypertension are risk factors. The diagnosis is further supported by the presence of neurologic deficits on examination, such as right-sided pronator drift, numbness in the right leg, and unsteady gait. The multiple deep white matter lesions on cranial MRI represent previous lacunar infarcts.

images.title: Subcortical atherosclerotic encephalopathy 1/2
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Abnormal low attenuation zones are seen in the periventricular white matter adjacent to the frontal and temporal horns of the lateral ventricles (green overlay). The cerebral sulci (examples indicated by red overlay) and ventricles are also prominent.These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

answers.explanation_why: Frontotemporal dementia is associated with personality changes (e.g., apathy) and eventual decline in cognitive function. Physical examination may show pyramidal signs such as a pronator drift. However, cranial MRI is more likely to show atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes than white matter lesions. Other features of frontotemporal dementia include disinhibition, loss of empathy, binge eating, and exaggerated emotional display.

images.title: Frontotemporal dementia
images.description: MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's cognitive decline and apathy are possible features of Alzheimer disease, which is the most common cause of dementia in older adults. However, Alzheimer disease typically has a more insidious onset and slow progression with early memory loss rather than a rapid stepwise deterioration in executive function. Moreover, Alzheimer disease is unlikely to manifest with neurologic deficits on physical examination (e.g., pronator drift, numbness, abnormal gait) and MRI would show cerebral atrophy rather than white matter lesions.

images.title: Cerebral atrophy in Alzheimer disease 1/3
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbanceThere is bilateral cerebral atrophy, with prominent sulci (green overlay).Multiple small hyperintense foci in the white matter (examples outlined) are enlarged perivascular spaces (Virchow-Robin spaces).

answers.explanation_why: Major depressive disorder is the most common cause of pseudodementia, for which this patient's age is a risk factor. Apathy is a feature of major depressive disorder; however, this patient does not meet the clinical criteria for depression. Moreover, pseudodementia is unlikely to present with neurologic deficits on physical examination (e.g., pronator drift, numbness, abnormal gait) and is not associated with white matter lesions on cranial MRI.

Lewy body dementia causes a variable sequence of symptoms that may include forgetfulness, confusion, and unsteady gait. However, physical examination would more likely show extrapyramidal motor symptoms (e.g., bradykinesia) than focal neurologic deficits (e.g., numbness, pronator drift). Other common features of Lewy body dementia not present in this patient include visual hallucinations and rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder. A cranial MRI would show regional cerebral atrophy rather than white matter lesions.

This patient's mood changes, forgetfulness, and bradycardia are possible features of hypothyroidism. However, this condition is not associated with focal neurologic deficits (e.g., numbness, pronator drift, abnormal gait). Other common features of hypothyroidism include fatigue, cold intolerance, skin and hair changes, weight gain, and constipation. This patient's bradycardia can be explained by metoprolol use and his mood changes and forgetfulness are more likely due to the abnormalities seen in his MRI.

Vitamin B_12 deficiency can cause a variety of neuropsychiatric symptoms, including apathy, forgetfulness, numbness, and unsteady gait. However, neuropathy would more likely be symmetrical and abnormal cranial MRI findings would be unlikely. Moreover, vitamin B_12 deficiency typically manifests with signs of anemia (e.g., fatigue, pallor), scleral icterus, or glossitis.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 66 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: African-American, self-identified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I need to go to the bathroom all the time.”
History of Present Illness:

1-year history of frequent urination

urinates every 2–3 hours during the day and wakes up at least 3 times at night to urinate
has had 2 episodes of cystitis treated with antibiotics in the past 4 months

has a weak urinary stream

has not noticed any blood in the urine
does not have any involuntary leakage of urine, pain with urination, or ejaculatory dysfunction

Past Medical History: 

type 2 diabetes mellitus, well-controlled 
nephrolithiasis, treated with percutaneous nephrolithotomy
essential tremor

Medications:

metformin
canagliflozin
propranolol

Allergies:
sulfa drugs
Psychosocial History:

sexually active with his wife; does not use condoms consistently
has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years

drinks one to two glasses of beer weekly

Appearance: no acute distress
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm; normal S_1, S_2, S_4 gallop
Abdominal: overweight; no tenderness, guarding, masses, bruits, or hepatosplenomegaly
Extremities: no joint erythema, edema, or warmth; dorsalis pedis, radial, and femoral pulses intact 
Genitourinary: no lesions or discharge
Rectal: slightly enlarged, smooth, nontender prostate
Neurologic: alert and oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal neurologic deficits

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

hint: This patient presents with two storage lower urinary tract symptoms (urinary frequency, nocturia) and one voiding lower urinary tract symptom (weak urinary stream). Additional manifestations of this patient's condition include a sensation of incomplete emptying.
learning_objective: Recognize benign prostatic hyperplasia.

answers.explanation_why: Neurogenic bladder can occur as a complication of diabetic autonomic neuropathy and cause recurrent UTIs as a result of incomplete urinary emptying. However, this patient's diabetes is well-controlled, and diabetic autonomic neuropathy causes a flaccid neurogenic bladder (urinary retention with overflow incontinence) by impairing bladder filling sensation and decreasing sphincter tone. Irregular, small-volume leakage of urine without an urge to void would be expected in this condition. An enlarged prostate in this patient suggests a different diagnosis.

Bladder calculi, which develop as a result of urinary stasis caused by incomplete emptying of the bladder, can cause increased urinary frequency and a weak urinary stream. However, they most commonly cause painless hematuria, dysuria, or abdominal pain, none of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, this condition does not cause an enlarged prostate.

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that promotes renal glucose excretion and causes osmotic diuresis. Although its adverse effects include polyuria and an increased rate of UTIs, it does not result in voiding lower urinary tract symptoms. Propranolol and metformin are not typically associated with lower urinary tract symptoms. An enlarged prostate in this patient suggests a different diagnosis.

Acute prostatitis can manifest with irritative and obstructive urinary tract symptoms, including frequency, nocturia, and a weak urinary stream. Rectal examination may reveal an enlarged prostate. However, the prostate is usually extremely tender on palpation. In addition, acute prostatitis typically manifests with systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, dysuria, and pelvic or perineal pain, none of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, this patient's 1-year history of urinary symptoms suggests a condition that has a more insidious course.

Prostate cancer is a malignancy that is more common among African-Americans and results in an enlarged prostate. However, it typically manifests with a nodular, not smooth, prostate. In addition, prostate cancer is generally slow-growing and most commonly located in the periphery of the prostate, not close to the urethra. Symptoms of urethral compression (e.g., weak stream), therefore, typically only occur in patients with advanced disease. This patient does not have manifestations of advanced prostate cancer (e.g., fatigue, weight loss, hematuria, bone pain from metastatic disease).

Urethral strictures can cause a weak urinary stream and recurrent UTIs. However, this condition is not typically associated with urinary frequency or nocturia and does not result in an enlarged prostate. In addition, most patients with urethral strictures have a history of prior urethral instrumentation and/or urogenital trauma. This patient had a urologic procedure (nephrolithotomy), but it was conducted via a percutaneous approach.

Uncomplicated lower urinary tract symptoms in addition to an enlarged prostate on physical examination are typical clinical features of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition that affects a majority of men > 60 years of age in the US. BPH causes compression of the urethra, which leads to bladder outlet obstruction. Incomplete voiding results in urinary stasis, which predisposes to urinary tract infections. Patients who are suspected of having BPH should receive a urinalysis to evaluate for UTI and hematuria. First-line treatment of BPH consists of behavioral modifications (e.g., restriction of fluid intake before bedtime, avoidance of caffeine and alcohol) and pharmacologic therapy with alpha-blockers (e.g., tamsulosin).

question_text: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of decreased sexual performance for the past 2 years. He reports that it takes longer for his penis to become erect, and he cannot maintain an erection for as long as before. His ejaculations have become less forceful. Once he has achieved an orgasm, he requires several hours before he can have another orgasm. He has been happily married for 40 years and he has no marital conflicts. His only medication is esomeprazole for gastroesophageal reflux disease. Examination shows coarse dark pubic and axillary hair. The skin of his lower extremity is warm to the touch; pedal pulses and sensation are intact. Rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged prostate with no masses. His fasting serum glucose is 96 mg/dL and his prostate-specific antigen is 3.9 ng/mL (N < 4). Which of the following etiologies is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of decreased sexual performance for the past 2 years. He reports that it takes longer for his penis to become erect, and he cannot maintain an erection for as long as before. His ejaculations have become less forceful. Once he has achieved an orgasm, he requires several hours before he can have another orgasm. He has been happily married for 40 years and he has no marital conflicts. His only medication is esomeprazole for gastroesophageal reflux disease. Examination shows coarse dark pubic and axillary hair. The skin of his lower extremity is warm to the touch; pedal pulses and sensation are intact. Rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged prostate with no masses. His fasting serum glucose is 96 mg/dL and his prostate-specific antigen is 3.9 ng/mL (N < 4). Which of the following etiologies is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
hint: Laboratory testing would reveal a normal testosterone level and decreased sperm production.
learning_objective: Recognize physiologic changes in male sexual function due to aging.

answers.explanation_why: Erectile dysfunction can be a manifestation of underlying vascular disease, often associated with conditions such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and peripheral artery disease. This patient's medical history and physical examination (warm lower extremities, intact pedal pulses and sensation) are not suggestive of a vascular etiology of his condition.

Erectile dysfunction can be caused by various classes of medications such as antihypertensives (e.g., beta-blockers, thiazide diuretics), antidepressants (e.g., SSRIs), and dopamine antagonists (e.g., antipsychotics). The patient is currently treated with esomeprazole, which is not associated with erectile dysfunction.

Psychogenic erectile dysfunction may develop due to psychosocial stress (e.g., relationship trouble, trauma) or in association with an underlying psychiatric condition (e.g., depression, anxiety disorder). However, this patient does not report any marital conflicts nor does he demonstrate any symptoms of a psychiatric condition.

Prostate cancer is not a direct cause of erectile dysfunction, but treatment for this condition can lead to erectile dysfunction through the use of antiandrogen therapy or as a result of surgical excision. This patient's physical examination shows symmetrical growth of the prostate with no masses and normal prostate-specific antigen, which is consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Neurogenic causes of erectile dysfunction (ED) include stroke, trauma that affects the brain and/or spinal cord, and neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis, Parkinson disease), none of which are seen in this patient. Patients with neurogenic ED typically cannot develop erections. While this man is having difficulty obtaining and maintaining his erection, he is still able to develop an erection.

Physiologic changes in male sexual function due to aging include delays in obtaining and maintaining an erection, longer refractory period between orgasms, and decreased ejaculate force and volume, which this patient describes. These are normal changes that progress gradually with advancing age, and they are not reflective of hormonal changes or decreased sexual desire.

question_text: An 84-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son for a follow-up examination. Two weeks ago, she was discharged from the hospital, where she was treated for an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. She reports occasional lightheadedness when she gets up from a sitting position but feels otherwise well. The son reports that the patient has had increased difficulty hearing over the past few years. She lives with her husband, who has used a wheelchair since a motorcycle accident 38 years ago. She also has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, panic disorder, migraine headaches, and insomnia. Her current medications include albuterol, ipratropium bromide, fluoxetine, lisinopril, rosiglitazone, topiramate, lorazepam, and over-the-counter fish oil supplements. Her vital signs measured in the recumbent position are within normal limits. The current medications are most likely to increase the patient's risk of which of the following?
content_preview: An 84-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son for a follow-up examination. Two weeks ago, she was discharged from the hospital, where she was treated for an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. She reports occasional lightheadedness when she gets up from a sitting position but feels otherwise well. The son reports that the patient has had increased difficulty hearing over the past few years. She lives with her husband, who has used a wheelchair since a motorcycle accident 38 years ago. She also has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, panic disorder, migraine headaches, and insomnia. Her current medications include albuterol, ipratropium bromide, fluoxetine, lisinopril, rosiglitazone, topiramate, lorazepam, and over-the-counter fish oil supplements. Her vital signs measured in the recumbent position are within normal limits. The current medications are most likely to increase the patient's risk of which of the following?
hint: This patient is receiving lorazepam (a benzodiazepine) for insomnia, topiramate (an antiepileptic) for migraine, and fluoxetine (an SSRI) for her panic disorder; the concomitant use of these drugs is concerning. The Beers criteria are widely used guidelines targeted at reducing adverse events from polypharmacy in the geriatric population.
learning_objective: Recognize the risks of polypharmacy in the elderly, and recall the Beers criteria.

answers.explanation_why: The main risk factors for Clostridioides difficile infection are the use of certain antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin, fluoroquinolones, cephalosporins) and proton pump inhibitors. This patient is not currently taking any medications that would significantly increase her risk of C. difficile infection.

This patient is taking ipratropium, an antimuscarinic drug, which is associated with an increased risk of constipation. However, the risk from this inhaled antimuscarinic agent is relatively low if the patient does not concomitantly use other drugs that have antimuscarinic activity (e.g., muscarinic receptor antagonists, tricyclic antidepressants, first-generation antihistamines, antipsychotics) or cause constipation (e.g., opioids, calcium channel blockers, antacids containing aluminum hydroxide). A different complication is much more likely with this patient's polydrug regimen.

This patient is taking lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI), which can cause transient prerenal azotemia when therapy is initiated, but long-term ACEI use in a patient with diabetes mellitus and hypertension is renoprotective. Significant ACEI-induced prerenal azotemia is a possibility only if the patient has a condition in which the glomerular filtration rate is critically dependent on angiotensin II (e.g., hypovolemia, bilateral renal artery stenosis) or concomitantly uses a drug that can cause prerenal azotemia (e.g., NSAIDs). This patient does not have evidence of any such condition and none of her other medications cause prerenal azotemia.

Topiramate can cause postrenal azotemia as a result of nephrolithiasis.

The main risk factors for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding are the use of NSAIDs (which decrease mucosal-protective PGE_2), systemic corticosteroids (which impair mucosal tissue repair), and anticoagulants. SSRI use is only rarely associated with GI bleeding and this patient is not currently taking any medications that would significantly increase her risk of gastrointestinal bleeding; a different complication is much more likely with this patient's polydrug regimen.

According to the Beers criteria, physicians should avoid prescribing ≥ 3 CNS-active drugs in geriatric patients because combining these drugs can cause sedation, cognitive impairment, and delirium, which can increase the risk of falls and resulting fractures. CNS-active drugs include antidepressants (tricyclic antidepressants, SSRIs, SNRIs), antipsychotics, antiepileptics, benzodiazepines, nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics, and opioids. Older patients are especially sensitive to benzodiazepines. This patient's orthostatic presyncope and hearing loss are also risk factors for falls. In addition, there is a higher risk of fractures in this patient, who has risk factors for decreased bone mineral density (e.g., postmenopausal woman, glitazone use).

Polypharmacy is often unavoidable in older patients because of the presence of multiple comorbidities but can sometimes occur as a result of a prescription cascade. Polypharmacy is associated with a greater risk of poor patient compliance, medical errors, decreased therapeutic efficacy, and/or adverse drug reactions (due to drug-drug interactions). Strategies to avoid polypharmacy and its complications include adherence to the Beers criteria, medication reconciliation, and periodic medication reviews with the use of drug-interaction checkers.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has nontremor-dominant Parkinson disease that was diagnosed at the age of 68 after developing progressive bradykinesia and rigidity. He lives alone following the death of his wife 2 years ago. The patient's son, daughter-in-law, and grandchildren live nearby and help him with daily activities. Current medications include levodopa, carbidopa, and entacapone. He appears well. Neurologic examination shows mild hypomimia, bradydiadochokinesia, shortened steps, and mild gait shuffling. During the examination, the patient mentions that he drove himself to his appointment today because he does not want to feel like a burden on his son. The physician is concerned that the patient's illness and medications potentially impair his driving skills. The patient stresses that he has never had an accident in his life and is a very safe driver. He also states that he has felt isolated since his wife's passing and likes to meet up with old friends at a local bar. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has nontremor-dominant Parkinson disease that was diagnosed at the age of 68 after developing progressive bradykinesia and rigidity. He lives alone following the death of his wife 2 years ago. The patient's son, daughter-in-law, and grandchildren live nearby and help him with daily activities. Current medications include levodopa, carbidopa, and entacapone. He appears well. Neurologic examination shows mild hypomimia, bradydiadochokinesia, shortened steps, and mild gait shuffling. During the examination, the patient mentions that he drove himself to his appointment today because he does not want to feel like a burden on his son. The physician is concerned that the patient's illness and medications potentially impair his driving skills. The patient stresses that he has never had an accident in his life and is a very safe driver. He also states that he has felt isolated since his wife's passing and likes to meet up with old friends at a local bar. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?
hint: The physician must balance responsibility to public safety with the welfare of the individual patient.
learning_objective: Recognize the physician's responsibility regarding a patient's driving capacity and public safety.

answers.content: "You should not feel that you are a burden on your son. I'm sure he will be happy to drive you."
answers.explanation_why: A physician should encourage patients to communicate with their family members and seek help when necessary. However, it is inappropriate for the physician to presume that the patient's son would be willing to drive for the patient. The physician should instead explore the patient's reasons for feeling like a burden on his son, rather than simply instructing him not to feel this way. Moreover, in this case, it is critical to inform the patient that his current condition impairs his ability to drive safely; a different reaction would, therefore, be appropriate.

answers.content: "I understand that you need your car to stay mobile, but without an official evaluation of your driving capacity, you should not be driving anywhere."
answers.explanation_why:
Irrespective of state laws, if a physician believes that a patient cannot drive safely, the physician must share their concerns with the patient and ask them to stop driving until they have been evaluated and treated by a driver rehabilitation specialist. Alternatively, the patient can be recleared for driving by the state licensing authority (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles). However, the laws for reporting impaired drivers differ between states.

Most states have voluntary reporting laws, under which a physician is not required to disclose a patient's driving impairment to the state licensing authority but are protected from a breach of patient confidentiality if they do so. Some states have mandatory reporting laws, which require physicians to report any patient with driving impairment to the state licensing authority. In states with voluntary or mandatory reporting laws, the physician can be held liable for a motor vehicle accident involving the impaired driver if the physician does not report the driving impairment. A few states do not have any reporting laws and require the physician to obtain the patient's consent before disclosing driving impairment to the authorities. In these states, the physician cannot be held liable for a motor vehicle accident involving the impaired driver if the physician does not have consent to disclose driver impairment.

answers.content: "I have a duty to public safety and unfortunately, I must inform the police that you are still driving."
answers.explanation_why: In states with mandatory reporting laws, the physician has an obligation to report patients with conditions that impair driving ability. However, the state licensing authority (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles) rather than the police should be informed in this scenario. The physician needs to inform the police only if the patient divulges a criminal act to the physician (e.g., hit-and-run, alcohol-related car accident).

answers.content: "I would advise you to stop driving, but I cannot tell you what to do. Just be aware that it is solely your responsibility if something bad happens."
answers.explanation_why: When the patient has a condition that limits their ability to drive safely, the physician must advise the patient to stop driving. However, in most states, if the patient continues to drive against medical advice and the physician does not report the patient to state licensing authorities, the physician can also be held liable for injuries that occur from a motor vehicle accident involving the patient.

answers.content: "I understand this is a difficult situation for you, but I have to ask you to surrender your driver's license now."
answers.explanation_why: The physician cannot ask a patient to surrender their driver's license. The state licensing authorities (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles) rather than a physician should determine the patient's inability to drive safely.

question_text: An 81-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She lives in a senior living facility in the Midwestern United States. There have been several cases of heavy metal poisoning through drinking water in her state, and she is concerned about potential exposure to toxic substances. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 153 cm (5 ft) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. Pulse is 76/min and regular, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Which of the following neurologic examination findings in this patient would necessitate immediate investigation?
content_preview: An 81-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She lives in a senior living facility in the Midwestern United States. There have been several cases of heavy metal poisoning through drinking water in her state, and she is concerned about potential exposure to toxic substances. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 153 cm (5 ft) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Pulse is 76/min and regular, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Which of the following neurologic examination findings in this patient would necessitate immediate investigation?
hint: This finding can be observed on examination of the cranial nerves.
learning_objective: Recognize abnormal neurologic examination findings, and recall conditions that necessitate immediate investigation.

answers.explanation_why: High-frequency, progressive, bilateral hearing loss in an older patient suggests presbycusis, which affects more than 50% of individuals at the age of 75 years, with increasing prevalence in older age groups. This condition is caused by age-related damage to hair cells at the base of the cochlea. Although otoscopy and audiometry would eventually be indicated to establish the diagnosis, high-frequency hearing loss is an expected finding in older patients and does not require immediate investigation.

Vertical or rotatory nystagmus on neurologic examination is considered abnormal in all age groups and warrants immediate investigation. Causes for vertical nystagmus include vestibular conditions (e.g., anterior and posterior semicircular canal BPPV), severe alcohol intoxication, drug side effects (e.g., phencyclidine, lithium, carbamazepine, phenytoin), Wernicke encephalopathy, and CNS lesions (e.g., bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia in multiple sclerosis, cerebellar lesions). In contrast, although horizontal nystagmus is most frequently pathological, it can occur physiologically (e.g., end-gaze nystagmus) in all age groups. Other neurophthalmological findings considered normal in older patients (especially those aged over 80 years) are sluggish convergence, sluggish pupillary reflex, decreased upward gaze (while lateral and downward movements usually remain intact), and impaired accommodation (presbyopia).

images.title: Characterization of nystagmus by direction
images.description: In jerk nystagmus, there is a slow drift phase followed by a fast corrective phase. The name of the nystagmus is determined by the direction of movement in the fast phase (left horizontal, right horizontal, downbeat, upbeat, clockwise, or counterclockwise).

answers.content: Decreased vibration sensation in the great toe
answers.explanation_why: A decreased sensation of vibration in the distal lower extremities is common in older patients. It can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons and does not require immediate investigation if it is an isolated finding. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if the decreased sensation of vibration occurs alongside additional signs and symptoms (e.g., signs of ischemia, ulcers, loss of reflexes, concomitant involvement of upper extremities, changes to other types of sensation).

Decreased sense of smell (hyposmia) is a common finding in older patients, affecting more than 60% of individuals aged ≥ 80 years. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of olfactory neurons. The isolated finding of hyposmia/anosmia in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Hyposmia in patients < 60 years of age should raise concern for an underlying disease (e.g., Parkinson disease) and further diagnostic workup might be indicated.

Diminished or absent ankle jerk reflexes are a common finding in older patients. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons, which results in diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes. The isolated finding of absent ankle jerk reflexes in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if this finding occurs with additional signs and symptoms, e.g., muscle weakness, sensory changes, constitutional symptoms, asymmetry, back pain.

question_text: A 79-year-old man is brought to the physician because of abdominal pain for the past 5 days. He had a bowel movement 6 hours ago that was watery but not bloody. He has not had any unexpected weight changes. He lives in a nursing care facility and has been bedridden for the past 4 years. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and vascular dementia. His medications are amlodipine, lisinopril, insulin, and aspirin. He has had no recent changes in his diet. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is mildly distended, and there is mild tenderness to palpation diffusely. There are palpable masses in the lower abdomen. Bowel sounds are decreased. Digital rectal examination shows hard stool. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 79-year-old man is brought to the physician because of abdominal pain for the past 5 days. He had a bowel movement 6 hours ago that was watery but not bloody. He has not had any unexpected weight changes. He lives in a nursing care facility and has been bedridden for the past 4 years. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and vascular dementia. His medications are amlodipine, lisinopril, insulin, and aspirin. He has had no recent changes in his diet. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is mildly distended, and there is mild tenderness to palpation diffusely. There are palpable masses in the lower abdomen. Bowel sounds are decreased. Digital rectal examination shows hard stool. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Diffuse abdominal pain and distention, palpable masses in the lower abdomen, and hard stool on digital rectal examination are consistent with fecal impaction. Patients with fecal impaction can develop paradoxical diarrhea with leakage of watery stool past the impacted segment of the rectum.
learning_objective: Recognize fecal impaction, and choose the most appropriate initial intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Exploratory laparotomy is rarely required in patients with fecal impaction. It can be considered if there are signs of impending bowel perforation or ischemia (e.g., severe abdominal tenderness), which is not the case here. A more conservative treatment modality should be tried first.
A regular physical therapy regimen is an effective strategy for preventing the recurrence of fecal impaction but will not resolve an acute case of fecal impaction.

answers.content: Place a nasogastric tube and administer polyethylene glycol
answers.explanation_why: Administration of polyethylene glycol through a nasogastric tube is unlikely to clear a distal fecal impaction. However, after disimpaction via another method, it may be considered for softening the stool and facilitating evacuation of the colon.

Colonoscopy with a snare can be used to clear a fecal impaction in the distal colon via fragmentation. However, this method is only used in cases in which more conservative methods of treatment have failed to disimpact the bowel. A different treatment modality should be tried before considering colonoscopy in this patient.

Fecal impaction is most commonly seen in older adults with reduced mobility, such as this patient. The initial management of fecal impaction involves manual fragmentation of the compacted feces. This procedure can be followed with warm water or mineral oil enemas to soften the stool and facilitate further evacuation of the colon. Once the fecal impaction is treated, lifestyle modifications such as a high-fiber diet and physical therapy should be initiated, together with a maintenance bowel regimen (e.g., osmotic laxative therapy) to prevent recurrence. Untreated fecal impaction can lead to complications such as intestinal obstruction, intestinal perforation, stercoral ulcers, stercoral colitis, and fistulas.

Digital rectal examination may not detect a fecal impaction if the location is in the proximal rectum or sigmoid colon. In these cases, an x-ray of the abdomen may show large, speckled, low-density opacities within distended loops of the large bowel and rectum.

question_text: A 76-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He feels well overall but is concerned about some lesions on his neck that his wife noticed a while ago. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows lesions scattered across his neck and axilla. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 76-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He feels well overall but is concerned about some lesions on his neck that his wife noticed a while ago. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination shows lesions scattered across his neck and axilla. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The multiple pedunculate appendices with narrow stalks are benign outgrowths of normal skin.
learning_objective: Recognize skin tags (acrochordons).

answers.explanation_why: Dermatofibromas are benign asymptomatic skin lesions that manifest as slow-growing nodules on the skin. In contrast to this patient's lesions, dermatofibromas tend to appear on the lower extremities, are not pedunculated, and do not have a stalk. In addition, dermatofibromas are more common in women, occur at any age, and manifest with a characteristic dimple sign.

images.title: Dermatofibroma
images.description: A solitary, pigmented, firm circular lesion is visible. Upon pinching of the lesion, the overlaying skin retracts inwards (dimple sign).This appearance is suggestive of a dermatofibroma, which usually manifests as a nodule.

answers.explanation_why: Seborrheic keratosis is a benign outgrowth of keratinocytes and is the most common benign skin tumor in older adults. Lesions can appear on the neck (as with this patient) as well as the trunk, dorsum of the hands, forearms, head, and/or face. However, seborrheic keratosis characteristically manifests as greasy, wax-like papules/plaques that have a “stuck-on” appearance and may become pruritic or bleed easily; they are not pedunculated lesions with a narrow stalk.

images.title: Seborrheic keratosis
images.description: A sharply demarcated darkly pigmented papule with a greasy nodular surface is visible. The papule appears to be stuck onto the skin.This is the typical appearance of seborrheic keratosis, a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in the elderly.

answers.explanation_why: Skin tags (acrochordons) are benign outgrowths of normal skin that appear as pedunculated appendices with narrow stalks. The prevalence is 50–60% in individuals aged over 50 years and increases with age. The etiology of skin tags is not fully understood, but they tend to affect areas of the body that experience friction, such as the lower neck, axilla, inframammary fold, and inguinal region. Skin tags are also associated with diabetes and obesity and may be a sign of insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome. Because skin tags are benign lesions, intervention is typically not necessary, but they may be removed for cosmetic purposes using fine-grade scissors, cryosurgery, or electrodesiccation.

Warts are benign skin lesions resulting from hyperkeratosis and hyperplasia of the epidermis that is typically due to human papillomavirus. In contrast to this patient's lesions, warts manifest as skin-colored, scaly papules/plaques that have a cauliflower-like appearance; they are not pedunculated and do not have a stalk. Common warts occur on the elbows, knees, fingers, and palm while flat warts occur on the face, dorsal hands, and legs, plantar warts on the soles of feet, and anogenital warts on the anus and/or genitals.

images.title: Common warts
images.description: Partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are seen on the dorsal surface of the hand at the level of the metacarpophalangeal joint

answers.explanation_why: Benign acanthosis nigricans manifests as velvety, hyperpigmented plaques on the skin. Acanthosis nigricans occurs in intertriginous zones (e.g., neck, axial, and/or inframammary fold) and is associated with obesity and diabetes. However, these lesions are associated with symmetrical thickening of the skin and, in some cases, pruritus. Furthermore, they are not pedunculated and do not have a stalk.

images.title: Acanthosis nigricans
images.description: Hyperpigmentation, hyperkeratosis, and numerous skin tags (papillomatosis) are visible on the right axilla.These findings are consistent with acanthosis nigricans.

images.title: Acrochordons (skin tags)
images.description: Multiple dark-colored pedunculated papules are visible.

question_text: A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department an hour after falling on the road while taking her dog for a walk. She says that she has not lost consciousness but “simply tripped over a rock.” A similar event happened 2 weeks ago when she fell while grocery shopping. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her family history is significant for Parkinson disease. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks one to two glasses of wine each week. Current medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, aspirin, metformin, and empagliflozin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. Examination shows an abrasion on her right knee and a deep cut on her right hand. Neurologic examination shows normal sensation to pinprick and vibration. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the left lower limb and 2+ in the right lower limb. She was able to get up out of her chair and walk to the wall and back to the chair without any problems. Which of the following is the most important risk factor for future falls in this patient?
content_preview: A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department an hour after falling on the road while taking her dog for a walk. She says that she has not lost consciousness but “simply tripped over a rock.” A similar event happened 2 weeks ago when she fell while grocery shopping. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her family history is significant for Parkinson disease. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks one to two glasses of wine each week. Current medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, aspirin, metformin, and empagliflozin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. Examination shows an abrasion on her right knee and a deep cut on her right hand. Neurologic examination shows normal sensation to pinprick and vibration. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the left lower limb and 2+ in the right lower limb. She was able to get up out of her chair and walk to the wall and back to the chair without any problems. Which of the following is the most important risk factor for future falls in this patient?
hint: The “Timed Up and Go” test is used to assess musculoskeletal function and postural stability in patients who have fallen. The patient is asked to get up from a chair, walk a certain distance, turn around, walk back, and sit down again.
learning_objective: Recall the main risk factor for future falls in older individuals.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's history of previous falls is the main risk factor for future falls. Falls in older individuals are usually due to a combination of age-related factors (e.g., lower-extremity weakness, cognitive and/or visual impairment), underlying medical conditions (e.g., Parkinson disease, osteoarthritis of the knee, orthostatic hypotension), and environmental hazards (e.g., slippery surfaces). Certain medications, such as benzodiazepines, increase the risk of falling. Patients who have fallen should undergo a risk assessment that involves testing of visual acuity, cognitive, neurological, musculoskeletal, and hearing function, postural vital signs, and past medical history including information about the circumstances of the current as well as previous falls. Strategies to prevent further falls include minimizing medications, physical therapy, and modifying the older individual's home environment.

While medication use is an important risk factor for falls, this patient's current medications are not known to pose a risk. Drugs commonly associated with an increased risk of falling include central nervous system active drugs (e.g., antipsychotics, benzodiazepines, antidepressants) and vasodilators.

Patients with peripheral neuropathy are at increased risk for falls due to progressive loss of sensation and weakness in the distal lower extremities. Though this patient has diabetes and is therefore at risk for developing peripheral neuropathy, her neurological exam showed no abnormal findings.

Orthostatic hypotension is common in older persons and is often associated with falls. While orthostatic hypotension is a known side effect of antihypertensive agents, ACE inhibitors such as enalapril are not implicated. Moreover, orthostatic hypotension typically manifests with symptoms such as dizziness, lightheadedness, and possibly loss of consciousness upon standing, none of which are reported by this patient.

Underlying chronic diseases such as Parkinson disease (PD) are an important risk factor for falls. While this patient's family history of PD raises her risk of developing this condition, she shows no signs or symptoms of PD.
Though heavy alcohol use is a known risk factor for falls, light use, such as the one to two glasses of wine this patient drinks each week, is not associated with an increased risk of falling.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because his wife is worried about a lesion on his face. She first noticed it 4 months ago and thinks it has grown but she is unsure. The patient says he feels well and that the lesion does not bother him. He has a 10-year history of hypertension. His family history is unremarkable. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a soft, painless, 5-mm papule on the right cheek; a photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because his wife is worried about a lesion on his face. She first noticed it 4 months ago and thinks it has grown but she is unsure. The patient says he feels well and that the lesion does not bother him. He has a 10-year history of hypertension. His family history is unremarkable. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a soft, painless, 5-mm papule on the right cheek; a photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The photograph shows a sharply demarcated and darkly pigmented papule that has a “stuck-on” appearance. This type of lesion in an older individual is characteristic of seborrheic keratosis.
learning_objective: Recognize seborrheic keratosis, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why:
Seborrheic keratosis is a benign, slow-growing lesion that is commonly seen in older individuals. For asymptomatic lesions, such as the one seen here, treatment is generally not necessary and reassurance with follow-up is sufficient. If atypical features are present (e.g., asymmetry, rapid change or growth, ulceration) or if the diagnosis is unclear, a biopsy may be indicated. Treatment with cryotherapy, laser therapy, or surgical excision is appropriate for cosmetic removal or if the lesion becomes symptomatic (e.g., pruritic, painful, or bleeds easily).

In patients with the sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses, known as the Leser-Trélat sign, further investigation is necessary because of this feature's association with malignancies such as lung cancer and gastrointestinal cancer.

Topical salicylic acid is the first-line treatment for warts, which can manifest as soft papules on the face (i.e., flat warts or verruca plana). However, flat warts are more common in younger individuals and they are usually flesh-colored, smooth, and flat, whereas this elderly patient's lesion is darkly pigmented and has a “stuck-on” appearance. Salicylic acid treatment is not recommended for seborrheic keratosis.

images.title: Common warts
images.description: Partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are seen on the dorsal surface of the hand at the level of the metacarpophalangeal joint

answers.explanation_why: A shave biopsy might be indicated to rule out malignancy in patients with pigmented skin lesions with atypical features (e.g., size > 6 mm; a recent change in shape, size, or color; irregular borders; asymmetry). This patient, however, has a small (5 mm), asymptomatic lesion that has not changed much over the past 4 months and has a waxy, “stuck-on” appearance, all of which are characteristic of seborrheic keratosis.

An excisional biopsy is indicated for pigmented lesions if there is suspicion for melanoma. According to the ABCDE rule for melanoma, a biopsy should be considered if the lesion is > 6 mm in diameter, asymmetric, has color variegation, irregular borders, or recent change in size, shape, or color. This patient's lesion has a waxy, “stuck-on” appearance characteristic of seborrheic keratosis, for which biopsy is not routinely indicated.

images.title: Superficial spreading melanoma
images.description: Upper backAn asymmetrical lesion approx. 16 mm in diameter is visible.This lesion fulfills the A (asymmetry), B (border irregularity), C (color variegation), and D (diameter > 6 mm) criteria for melanoma. The diagnosis should be confirmed by performing a full-thickness excisional biopsy.

answers.explanation_why: Cryotherapy is the most common treatment for seborrheic keratosis. However, cryotherapy is indicated in symptomatic lesions or if the patient requests treatment for cosmetic reasons, which is not the case here.

images.title: Seborrheic keratosis
images.description: A sharply demarcated darkly pigmented papule with a greasy, stuck-on appearance is visible.This is the typical appearance of seborrheic keratosis.

question_text: A 79-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter out of concern for memory loss. He previously worked in finance but now requires help paying his bills. One month ago, he got lost in his own neighborhood and could not find his way home. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurocognitive testing shows he is alert and oriented to person and place but does not know the year or month. During the examination, the physician names three unrelated objects clearly and slowly. The physician then immediately asks the patient to repeat the names of all three objects. Which of the following cognitive domains is being tested by the described task?
content_preview: A 79-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter out of concern for memory loss. He previously worked in finance but now requires help paying his bills. One month ago, he got lost in his own neighborhood and could not find his way home. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurocognitive testing shows he is alert and oriented to person and place but does not know the year or month. During the examination, the physician names three unrelated objects clearly and slowly. The physician then immediately asks the patient to repeat the names of all three objects. Which of the following cognitive domains is being tested by the described task?
hint: This physician is performing a test of the patient's immediate memory.
learning_objective: Recall the tests for immediate, short-term, and long-term memory.

answers.explanation_why: Orientation is the cognitive awareness of person, place, and time, and it is tested by assessing a patient's ability to recognize themselves (e.g., name), the time (e.g., month, day, year), and their physical location (e.g., city, state, country). For example, this patient is oriented to person and place but does not know the month or year. This patient, however, is being asked to perform a test of immediate memory.

The task of repeating three objects immediately after they have been named is a test of registration (also known as immediate memory or immediate recall). Registration is the shortest type of information storage. Registration is distinct from recent memory (also known as short-term memory), in which information is stored and then reproduced at a later point (e.g., naming the objects and then asking five minutes later for them to be repeated). Remote memory (also known as long-term memory) refers to memory of the distant past.

Remote memory (also known as long-term memory) refers to memory of the distant past. An example of testing this cognitive domain is asking the patient to remember something that occurred years ago. This patient, however, is being asked to perform a test of immediate memory.
Affect is an assessment of the type, range, and appropriateness of emotional expression based on the physician's observation of facial and bodily gestures, and tone of speech.

The task of naming the objects and then asking the patient five minutes later for them to be repeated is a test of short-term memory. This patient, however, is being asked to perform a test of immediate memory.

question_text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. Her medical history is significant for vasospastic angina controlled with diltiazem. She has not had menses for 15 years. Her mother died of myocardial infarction at the age of 75 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks alcohol occasionally. Her other medications are vitamin D and calcium supplements. The patient is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (115 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies, including serum calcium and creatinine concentrations, are within the reference ranges. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry scan shows a T-score of -2.7 SD. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. Her medical history is significant for vasospastic angina controlled with diltiazem. She has not had menses for 15 years. Her mother died of myocardial infarction at the age of 75 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks alcohol occasionally. Her other medications are vitamin D and calcium supplements. The patient is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (115 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies, including serum calcium and creatinine concentrations, are within the reference ranges. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry scan shows a T-score of -2.7 SD. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?
hint: A T-score ≤ -2.5 SD on dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scan and/or the presence of a fragility fracture are consistent with a diagnosis of osteoporosis, which most commonly affects postmenopausal women with a low BMI.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate initial treatment for osteoporosis.

answers.explanation_why: Estrogen is not approved for osteoporosis treatment because it is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer, venous thromboembolism, and stroke. However, it may be considered in women at high risk of fracture who are unable to tolerate first-line and second-line medications and have persistent menopausal symptoms. This patient has a history of vasospastic angina, which is a contraindication for estrogen therapy.

Teriparatide can be used in patients with osteoporosis who have contraindications and/or are unresponsive to the preferred initial treatment. Moreover, teriparatide can be considered as an alternative for patients with osteoporosis and a high risk of fracture (e.g., T-score ≤ -3 SD, a history of severe and/or multiple fractures). However, this patient has no history of fractures and a T-score of -2.7 SD.

Denosumab is indicated in patients with osteoporosis and impaired renal function or if the preferred initial treatment has failed. This patient's serum creatinine is normal; therefore, another initial treatment is indicated.

Oral bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate, risedronate) are the preferred initial treatment in patients with osteoporosis because these drugs prevent bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclasts and can significantly decrease the risk of fracture. Bisphosphonates should be taken in the morning and evening at least 30 minutes before meals, with plenty of water, and the patient should maintain an upright position for at least 30 minutes following intake to prevent esophagitis. Other side effects are osteonecrosis of the jaw and hypocalcemia. Contraindications to bisphosphonates include hypocalcemia, esophageal abnormalities, and decreased glomerular filtration rate. In case of contraindications or unresponsiveness to bisphosphonates, medications such as parathyroid hormone analogs (teriparatide), selective estrogen receptor modulators (raloxifene), or RANKL inhibitors (denosumab) may be used.

Sufficient intake of calcium and vitamin D is recommended as primary prevention and adjunct therapy for osteoporosis. Lifestyle modifications, such as physical activity (e.g., strength and balance training) and avoidance of alcohol, tobacco, and glucocorticoids, should be encouraged.

images.title: Mechanism of action: osteoporosis medication
images.description:
– Calcitonin: inhibits osteoclast activity and reduces renal and gastrointestinal resorption of calcium
– Romosozumab: a monoclonal antibody that binds sclerostin, promoting bone formation and inhibiting bone resorption
– Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs; e.g., raloxifene) and estrogens: suppress chemical mediators (e.g., cytokines, TGFb), resulting in inhibition of osteoclast bone resorption and promotion of osteoclast apoptosis
– Bisphosphonates (alendronate, risedronate): inhibit osteoclast activity and, therefore, bone resorption
– RANKL inhibitors (denosumab): bind to RANKL, preventing it from activating osteoclasts via the RANK receptor
– Strontium: activates osteoblasts and stimulates them to produce osteoprotegerin (OPG), which inhibits RANK-RANKL binding
– PTH/parathyroid analogs (teriparatide): promote both osteoblast and osteoclast activity but with the net result of increased bone mass
– Vitamin D: increases absorption of calcium and phosphate from the gastrointestinal tract

answers.content: No further pharmacotherapy is indicated at this time
answers.explanation_why: No further pharmacotherapy apart from lifestyle modifications (e.g., sufficient intake of calcium and vitamin D) is indicated in patients with osteopenia (i.e., T-score of -1 to -2.5 SD) who are not at high risk of fracture. This patient has osteoporosis for which additional pharmacotherapy is indicated to reduce the risk of fractures.

Raloxifene can be used in patients with osteoporosis who have contraindications and/or in those who are unresponsive to the preferred initial treatment. Raloxifene may also be used in patients with osteoporosis who require breast cancer prophylaxis. This patient has no family history of breast cancer. Furthermore, raloxifene increases the risk of thromboembolic events, which is already elevated in this patient who smokes.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 68 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have been falling down a lot lately.”
History of Present Illness:

several falls in the past 2 months; no major injuries
feels unsteady when walking
no loss of consciousness or vertigo

Past Medical History:

5-year history of Parkinson disease

3-year history of major depressive disorder with psychotic features; currently no depressive or psychotic symptoms
presbyopia, corrected with glasses; last visit to ophthalmologist 4 months ago

Medications:

carbidopa-levodopa
mirtazapine 

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug, food, or contact allergies
Family History:
mother and father deceased
Psychosocial History:

retired elementary school teacher
lives alone since his wife died 2 years ago
has two children who visit him frequently and a supportive network of friends

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

36.7°C
(98.1°F)

78/min
14/min
130/80 mm Hg
97% on RA

172 cm
(5 ft 8 in)
75 kg
(165 lb)
25 kg/m^2

Appearance: alert and well
HEENT: PERRLA
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: bowel sounds normoactive; soft, nontender
Extremities: several bruises of varying size, age, and color on forearms, knees, and shins bilaterally
Neurologic: reduced arm swing; mild resting tremor of the right hand; postural instability on pull test; findings stable compared to last visit 6 months ago.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 68 years Gender: M, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have been falling down a lot lately.” History of Present Illness: several falls in the past 2 months; no major injuries feels unsteady when walking no loss of consciousness or vertigo Past Medical History: 5-year history of Parkinson disease 3-year history of major depressive disorder with psychotic features; currently no depressive or psychotic symptoms presbyopia, corrected with glasses; last visit to ophthalmologist 4 months ago Medications: carbidopa-levodopa mirtazapine Vaccinations: up-to-date Allergies: no known drug, food, or contact allergies Family History: mother and father deceased Psychosocial History: retired elementary school teacher lives alone since his wife died 2 years ago has two children who visit him frequently and a supportive network of friends Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 36.7°C(98.1°F) 78/min 14/min 130/80 mm Hg 97% on RA 172 cm(5 ft 8 in) 75 kg(165 lb) 25 kg/m2 Appearance: alert and well HEENT: PERRLA Pulmonary: clear to auscultation Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs Abdominal: bowel sounds normoactive; soft, nontender Extremities: several bruises of varying size, age, and color on forearms, knees, and shins bilaterally Neurologic: reduced arm swing; mild resting tremor of the right hand; postural instability on pull test; findings stable compared to last visit 6 months ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Falls are a common problem, even in well-controlled Parkinson disease, mainly because of postural instability and unsteady gait.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for an elderly individual who experiences frequent falls.

answers.explanation_why: Physical therapy is indicated in all older adults with evidence of poor gait, strength, or balance (e.g., patients with Parkinson disease). In addition to physical therapy, this patient would benefit from a fall risk assessment to identify more personalized preventive measures (e.g., occupational therapy, home hazard assessment and modification). Falls are the leading cause of injury-related death in adults aged ≥ 65 years. All older adults should be counseled on fall prevention strategies and screened for fall risk annually, beginning with the question: “Have you fallen in the past year?” A fall risk assessment should be performed for individuals who screen positive for fall risk and those who present after an acute fall.

Although SSRIs like citalopram are generally safe and effective for treating depression in individuals with Parkinson disease, this patient has no indications for switching to another class of antidepressants (e.g., inadequate symptom control, adverse effects). While mirtazapine can cause drowsiness, SSRIs like citalopram have a higher risk of orthostatic hypotension and have been associated with an increased risk of falling in the elderly.

Initiating another medication for Parkinson disease, such as rotigotine, is indicated in patients with refractory symptoms or intolerable adverse effects that require dose reduction of the current regimen. This patient's symptoms are well controlled with carbidopa-levodopa, and another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

While visual acuity testing is an important part of fall prevention, this patient's presbyopia is corrected with glasses, and his last ophthalmology visit was four months ago. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

Previously, vitamin D was administered routinely to patients with an increased risk of falls but currently, the USPSTF advises against routine vitamin D supplementation for community-dwelling older patients at increased risk for falls unless evidence of osteoporosis or vitamin D deficiency is present. It would be appropriate to screen for vitamin D deficiency and osteoporosis in this patient, but another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

question_text: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for a routine examination. In the past 6 months, the patient was hospitalized twice because of a urinary tract infection. She has Alzheimer disease, diabetes mellitus, and chronic urinary incontinence, for which she has an indwelling urinary catheter. She is bedridden and lives with her daughter, who is her next of kin. Current medications include rivastigmine and metformin. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is alert and oriented to person and place but not to time. She can name three objects shown by the physician and recalls two after 3 minutes. She makes multiple errors during a serial sevens test. The physician suggests replacing the indwelling urinary catheter with a suprapubic catheter in order to reduce the risk of further urinary tract infections. The physician informs the patient about the procedure as well as the risks and benefits of suprapubic catheter use compared to continued transurethral catheter use. The patient is able to repeat the information in her own words. When asked for her decision, she says “I will keep the current catheter because I do not want to undergo surgery.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for a routine examination. In the past 6 months, the patient was hospitalized twice because of a urinary tract infection. She has Alzheimer disease, diabetes mellitus, and chronic urinary incontinence, for which she has an indwelling urinary catheter. She is bedridden and lives with her daughter, who is her next of kin. Current medications include rivastigmine and metformin. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is alert and oriented to person and place but not to time. She can name three objects shown by the physician and recalls two after 3 minutes. She makes multiple errors during a serial sevens test. The physician suggests replacing the indwelling urinary catheter with a suprapubic catheter in order to reduce the risk of further urinary tract infections. The physician informs the patient about the procedure as well as the risks and benefits of suprapubic catheter use compared to continued transurethral catheter use. The patient is able to repeat the information in her own words. When asked for her decision, she says “I will keep the current catheter because I do not want to undergo surgery.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A patient has decision-making capacity when they can demonstrate an understanding of the medical information, show an appreciation of the relevant facts, communicate a choice, and express the reasoning for the choice.
learning_objective: Recognize the components of decision-making capacity and respect patient autonomy.

answers.explanation_why: If a patient's capacity is impaired, their advance health directive should be used to guide decision-making. In the absence of an advance health care directive, a surrogate decision-maker is chosen (typically the patient's next of kin). This patient has demonstrated the capacity to make her own medical decisions.

answers.content: Consult with the local ethics committee
answers.explanation_why: Consulting with an ethics committee can be useful in the case of an ethical dilemma. However, decision-making capacity should be determined by the treating physician. This patient has demonstrated the capacity to make her own medical decisions.

Decision-making capacity should be determined by the treating physician, but a psychiatrist may be consulted when capacity is difficult to assess (e.g., in patients with severe mental illness). This patient has demonstrated the capacity to make her own medical decisions.

A patient may be temporarily incapacitated (e.g., due to intoxication or delirium), requiring treatment before reassessment of mental status. This patient has no temporary conditions that affect her capacity to make medical decisions.

answers.content: Keep the indwelling urinary catheter in place
answers.explanation_why: Capacity assessment should be based on the individual patient and the decision being made. This patient has demonstrated all four components of decision-making capacity, and her decision should be respected. She clearly expressed an understanding of the medical information and an appreciation of the relevant facts in her own words. Furthermore, she communicated her decision to keep the indwelling transurethral catheter and gave the reasoning for her choice. Although patients with dementia may have impaired cognitive abilities, it should not be assumed that they lack decision-making capacity; their capacity to make medical decisions is often intact.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine check-up. She feels well. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. Her mother had hypertension; there is no family history of osteoporosis. She experienced menopause at age 52. She drinks a glass of wine on holidays, walks her dog outdoors for 1 hour daily, and has never smoked. Her diet includes dairy, leafy green vegetables, and salmon. Physical examination and BMI findings are normal. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count, metabolic panel, serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D, and thyroid-stimulating hormone, show no abnormalities. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) has never been performed. She is interested in “doing whatever I can to keep my bones healthy.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine check-up. She feels well. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. Her mother had hypertension; there is no family history of osteoporosis. She experienced menopause at age 52. She drinks a glass of wine on holidays, walks her dog outdoors for 1 hour daily, and has never smoked. Her diet includes dairy, leafy green vegetables, and salmon. Physical examination and BMI findings are normal. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count, metabolic panel, serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D, and thyroid-stimulating hormone, show no abnormalities. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) has never been performed. She is interested in “doing whatever I can to keep my bones healthy.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Risk factors for osteoporosis include low body weight, smoking, a family history of osteoporosis, previous fractures, and long-term corticosteroid use.
learning_objective: Recognize vitamin D and calcium needs of postmenopausal  women with no risk factors.

answers.content: Recommend dietary intake of calcium and vitamin D
answers.explanation_why:
Dietary and lifestyle measures are the mainstay of osteoporosis prevention in postmenopausal women under 65 without risk factors. This includes an optimized intake of calcium and vitamin D, with recommended daily intakes of 1000–1200 mg of calcium and 800–1000 IU of vitamin D. Dietary sources are preferred over supplements unless a deficiency is present. Other preventive measures include physical exercise (e.g., strength training), smoking cessation, and limiting alcohol intake.

Screening for osteoporosis is indicated in women ≥ 65 years and those with risk factors (e.g., long-term corticosteroid use).

answers.content: Start 2000 IU daily oral vitamin D supplement
answers.explanation_why: High-dose vitamin D supplementation is reserved for patients with confirmed vitamin D deficiency and those at an increased risk of deficiency (e.g., due to malabsorption, minimal sun exposure). This patient’s vitamin D level is normal, and she gets regular sun exposure and has a balanced diet that includes food rich in vitamin D (e.g., salmon). Excess supplementation can increase the risk for adverse effects such as hypercalcemia and nephrolithiasis.

Bisphosphonates are indicated for the treatment of confirmed osteoporosis and in patients with osteopenia who are at increased risk of major osteoporotic fracture in the next 10 years. Bisphosphonates are not used for the primary prevention of osteoporosis.

Estrogen replacement therapy may reduce bone loss and fracture risk but is not recommended for the primary prevention of osteoporosis in asymptomatic postmenopausal women due to the increased risk for breast cancer, thromboembolism, and cardiovascular events.

DXA screening is recommended for women aged 65 or older and may be considered in younger women with significant risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., low body weight, smoking, family history of osteoporosis). At 62 years of age, with no risk factors, this patient does not meet the criteria for DXA screening.
