question_text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the ophthalmologist because of vision changes over the past several months. She has worn glasses for nearsightedness since adolescence and typically requires them for driving and distance vision. Recently, she has noticed that she does not need her glasses to read the newspaper or do close-up needlework. She reports no eye pain, redness, discharge, or floaters. Medical history is significant for hypertension treated with lisinopril. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Family history is unremarkable. She appears well. Visual acuity with her current distance correction is 20/20 in both eyes. Without correction, distance vision is 20/400 bilaterally. Near vision without correction is 20/25 in both eyes. Slit lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in both eyes. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's improved near vision?
content_preview: A 56-year-old woman comes to the ophthalmologist because of vision changes over the past several months. She has worn glasses for nearsightedness since adolescence and typically requires them for driving and distance vision. Recently, she has noticed that she does not need her glasses to read the newspaper or do close-up needlework. She reports no eye pain, redness, discharge, or floaters. Medical history is significant for hypertension treated with lisinopril. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Family history is unremarkable. She appears well. Visual acuity with her current distance correction is 20/20 in both eyes. Without correction, distance vision is 20/400 bilaterally. Near vision without correction is 20/25 in both eyes. Slit lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in both eyes. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's improved near vision?
hint: This patient presents with second sight, which is a temporary improvement in near vision.
learning_objective: Recognize presbyopia as a cause of improved near vision in a patient with myopia, and distinguish it from other causes of visual change.

answers.explanation_why: Presbyopia is the age-related loss of accommodation caused by decreased elasticity of the lens and typically begins in a patient's mid-40s. This condition can cause second sight, a temporary improvement in near vision without correction in previously myopic patients. Second sight occurs because the focal point of the lens shifts, partially compensating for its inability to accommodate. Visual acuity with distance correction remains normal.

Hypertensive retinopathy typically leads to gradual vision loss or visual field defects, not improved vision. In addition, funduscopic examination in this condition shows retinal vascular changes (e.g., arteriolar narrowing, cotton wool spots, hemorrhage).
Age-related macular degeneration leads to progressive central vision loss, not improved vision. In addition, funduscopic examination in this condition shows pigmentary changes and/or drusen.

Acute angle-closure glaucoma manifests with sudden onset of severe eye pain, headache, nausea, blurred vision, and a red, hard eye with elevated intraocular pressure, none of which is seen in this patient. In addition, this condition does not cause improved vision.

Cataract can cause second sight, in which myopic shift temporarily improves near vision. Cataract typically manifests with progressive, painless blurring of both distance and near vision, glare, and reduced acuity even with correction as the condition progresses. This patient presents with visual acuity with 20/20 distance correction, and slit lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Therefore, cataract is unlikely to be the cause of improved near vision in this patient.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 6-kg (13-lb) unintentional weight loss of over the past 3 months. He has also noticed intermittent blood mixed with his stools and a change in bowel habits, alternating between constipation and diarrhea. Three years ago, he was treated with eradication therapy for Helicobacter pylori infection. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and celiac disease diagnosed at age 24 years. He follows a strict gluten-free, pescatarian diet. Medications are lisinopril, atorvastatin, and an iron supplement. He drinks one glass of wine every other day. His body mass index is 23 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae and mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin concentration of 10.2 g/dL. Histopathology of a colon biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 6-kg (13-lb) unintentional weight loss of over the past 3 months. He has also noticed intermittent blood mixed with his stools and a change in bowel habits, alternating between constipation and diarrhea. Three years ago, he was treated with eradication therapy for Helicobacter pylori infection. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and celiac disease diagnosed at age 24 years. He follows a strict gluten-free, pescatarian diet. Medications are lisinopril, atorvastatin, and an iron supplement. He drinks one glass of wine every other day. His body mass index is 23 kg/m2. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae and mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin concentration of 10.2 g/dL. Histopathology of a colon biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for this patient's condition?
hint: The photomicrograph shows hyperchromatic cells, nuclei with atypical features, desmoplasia, and colonic glands extending into the submucosa, all of which indicate colonic adenocarcinoma. Weight loss, anemia, blood in the stool, and altered bowel habits are classic features of colorectal cancer.
learning_objective: Recognize histologic features of colorectal adenocarcinoma, and identify the most significant risk factor for its development.

answers.explanation_why: Heavy alcohol consumption is a modest risk factor for colorectal cancer, especially with chronic use. However, this patient only consumes one glass of wine every other day, which does not meet the threshold for heavy consumption.

Celiac disease is associated with an increased risk of enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma and small bowel adenocarcinoma but not with colorectal adenocarcinoma. Long-standing, untreated celiac disease can cause malabsorption and nutritional deficiencies, but this patient adheres to a gluten-free diet.
Chronic H. pylori infection is a well-established risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma and MALT lymphoma but has not been linked to colorectal cancer.

Increasing age (> 40 years) is the most significant risk factor for colorectal adenocarcinoma, with peak incidence between 70–80 years of age. Colorectal cancer incidence rises sharply with age, as the accumulation of genetic mutations and epigenetic alterations over time increases the likelihood of malignant transformation in colonic epithelial cells. Other risk factors include a history of adenomatous and serrated polyps, familial cancer syndromes (e.g., hereditary polyposis syndromes), inflammatory bowel disease, tobacco use, a diet of processed meat with low fiber, and heavy alcohol use. However, age remains the single strongest predictor of disease in older individuals without other risk factors. Therefore, screening guidelines prioritize older adults.

Some studies suggest that a low-fiber diet is a potential risk factor for colorectal cancer, but there is limited evidence to support the association. Furthermore, this patient adheres to a pescatarian diet, which may reduce the risk of colorectal cancer.

images.title: Colorectal adenocarcinoma (pT1)
images.description: Photomicrograph of colonic tissue (H&E stain)The hyperchromatic area on the right two-thirds of this image shows a moderately differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma. The cells lining the colonic glands appear hyperchromatic, with basally oriented nuclei with atypical features. The lumen of these glands contains necrotic debris. The colonic glands, which are typically only present in the mucosal layer, are visible in the submucosa, but not beyond (pT1). Goblet cells are absent. (They would appear as unstained cells between the lining epithelial cells.) Desmoplasia is identifiable as fibrous tissue surrounding the tumor cells.Normal colonic mucosa is identifiable on the left third of the image as paler staining tissue. Note the abundance of goblet cells.Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
